div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; regulation of alcoholic beverages generally, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-1 et seq.; authority of local authorities to license and regulate alcoholic beverage sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2; local regulation of sales on Sundays, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7; prohibited acts on licensed premises, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-40 et seq.; malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-1 et seq.; wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-1 et seq.; local licensing requirements for sale of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40 et seq.; requirements for sale of wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-40.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 4-1. - Purpose. This chapter has been enacted in accordance with a plan designed for the purposes, among others, of promoting the health and general welfare of the community: (1) To establish reasonable standards for the regulation and control of the licensing and sale of alcoholic beverages; (2) To protect and preserve schools; to give effect to existing land use; to protect those of minor age in the community; (3) To preserve certain residential areas, with reasonable considerations, among others, to the character of the areas and there peculiar suitability for particular uses, the congestion in the roads and streets, and with a general view of promoting desirable living conditions and sustaining stability of neighborhood and property values; and (4) To prevent undesirable persons from controlling the malt beverage industry. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-001, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-2. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Unless otherwise defined herein, the definitions contained within O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq., shall be applicable to this chapter. Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, from whatever source or by whatever process produced. Alcoholic beverage means and includes all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverage, wine, or fortified wine. Brown-bagging means the bringing, taking, or carrying of any alcoholic beverage into a business licensed to operate within the city; provided that bringing an alcoholic beverage into a house, apartment, room, or other units designed for private residential occupancy shall not fall within this definition. Interest in license shall be deemed to exist if the person involved is the outright owner of the license; a co-owner of the license; a partner in a partnership which owns all or any part of a license; a stockholder of a corporation organized for pecuniary gain which owns all or any part of a license; an owner, lessor, sub-lessor, or stockholder in any corporation organized for pecuniary gain owning or leasing any real estate which is occupied by a restaurant which sells malt beverages, or shares in any of the income or corpus of any trust fund or estate having an interest in one of the aforesaid establishments which sells malt beverages. Live means any activity or entertainment which is carried on by actual living person in the physical presence of the patrons. Live entertainment means entertainment for the benefit of patrons which is carried on in the actual physical presence of such patrons, including, but not limited to, dancing. Mainstream performance house means a theater, concert hall, auditorium, or similar establishment which regularly features live performances such as plays or concerts which are not distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on the depiction, description or display or the featuring of specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities and where such depiction, if any, is only incidental to the primary purpose of any performance. Malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops, or any similar product, or any combination of such products in water, containing not more than six percent alcohol by volume and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, small beer, and strong beer. The term does not include sake, known as Japanese rice wine. Passenger vehicle means a vehicle designed to carry ten or more passengers and used to carry passengers for profit or hire. Private residence means a house or dwelling wherein not less than one nor more than two families reside and shall not include an apartment house having facilities for housing more than two families, nor a boardinghouse or roominghouse where there are five or more boarders or roomers. Any building occupied as a residence located within an area zoned for business shall not be construed as a private residence. In addition, any residence outside the city limits shall not be considered a private residence for purposes of this chapter. Proper identification means any document issued by a governmental agency containing a description of the person, such person's photograph, or both, and giving such person's date of birth and includes, without being limited to, a passport, military identification card, driver's license, current identification card authorized under O.C.G.A. § 40-5-100 et seq. The term "proper identification" shall not include a birth certificate. Restaurant means any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are actually and regularly served, the place being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and seating capacity of at least 40 people, having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employee to prepare, cook, and serve suitable food for its guests. At least one meal per day shall be served at least six days per week, with the exception of holidays, vacations, and periods of re-decorating, and the serving of these meals shall be the principal business conducted. The serving of prepared food must equal not less than 50 percent of any such restaurant's monthly gross sales as certified to by the proprietor and his CPA. This certificate shall be given quarterly and shall state his total gross sales of any such establishment, gross sales of prepared food, and gross sale of malt beverages consumed on the premises. School means only such state, county, city, church, or other schools that teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools of this state and shall not include private schools where only specialized subjects such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations, and other special subjects are taught. Specified anatomical area. See definition in section 6-79. Specified sexual activities. See definition in section 6-79. Wine means any alcoholic beverage containing not more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries, or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term includes, but is not limited to, all sparkling wines, champagnes, combinations of such beverages, vermouths, special natural wines, rectified wines, and like products. The term does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. A liquid shall first be deemed to be a wine at that point in the manufacturing process when it conforms to the definition of wine contained in this section. (Ord. No. 80-2, § 80-001, 2-19-1980; Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-002, 2-14-1980; Ord. of 4-2-1991) State Law reference— Similar definitions, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq. Sec. 4-3. - Zoning requirements for licensed locations. No license shall be issued within the areas described in this chapter, unless the location has been zoned C-1 or C-2 under the zoning provisions of chapter 66. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-003, 2-14-1980; Ord. No. 80-2, § 80-002, 2-19-1980) Sec. 4-4. - Proximity of premises to churches, schools, colleges, public library, nursing homes or private residence. (a) No new license shall be issued for the sale of any beer, wine, malt beverages, or distilled spirits for a location nor shall any existing license be transferred to a new location which will be in or within 300 feet of a church building, school building, school grounds or college campus or within 75 feet of a private residence. (b) For the purpose of this section, distance shall be measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground. (c) Each application for a license shall show the location of the proposed building and the distance to the nearest church, nursing home, public library, school grounds, and private residence. (d) The school grounds and college campuses, referred to in this section, shall apply only to state, county, city or church school grounds and college campuses and to such other schools and colleges as teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of this state. (e) The provisions of this section shall not apply at any location for which a license has been issued prior to the adoption of this section, nor to the renewal of such license. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-004, 2-14-1980; Ord. No. 80-2, § 80-003, 2-19-1980) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21. Sec. 4-5. - Violations; penalties. (a) Any person who acquires a license or a renewal thereof in violation of this chapter by any misrepresentation or fraudulent statement or who, after acquiring a license, is found to have violated any of the provisions of this chapter, shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-15. (b) Any untrue or misleading information contained in, or material omission left out of an original, renewal, or transfer application for a license shall be cause for the denial thereof and, if any license has been granted under these circumstances, these shall be cause for revocation. (c) Revocation of a license for violation of this chapter shall be for a minimum of 12 months and a maximum of 24 months, the period to be determined at the discretion of the recorder. (d) A total of three separate and unrelated violations shall constitute grounds for permanent revocation. (e) A violation of the chapter by an employee or agent of the licensee shall be deemed a violation of the licensee. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-008, 2-14-1980) Secs. 4-6—4-28. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 4-29. - Open container restrictions. It shall be unlawful for any person to drink, or have in his possession an open container of any alcoholic beverage while: (1) On any public street, sidewalk, park, or other public place within the city, or upon or within any motor vehicle while on the streets, sidewalks, parks, and public places of the city; or (2) On private property, open to public view, without the express permission of the owner, agent, or person in lawful possession thereof. The provisions of this section shall not be deemed to prohibit the drinking of alcoholic beverages by passengers in passenger vehicles. (Ord. No. 89-10, 8-1-1989) Sec. 4-30. - Brown-bagging prohibited. Brown-bagging is prohibited in the city. Brown-bagging includes the following prohibited acts: (1) Any person who brown-bags; (2) Any person participating in consumption of any alcoholic beverage being brown-bagged; (3) Any person who consumes an alcoholic beverage on any premises holding a business license, except for those premises exempted from the definition of brown-bagging by virtue of the private residential character of the occupancy; (4) Any employee of the business establishment in whose presence brown-bagging knowingly or with reckless indifference occurs. (Ord. No. 96-13, 1996) Secs. 4-31—4-48. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - UNDERAGE PERSONS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Sale to underage persons prohibited, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-3-23, 3-3-23.1; restrictions on employment of underage persons, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-24.
Sec. 4-49. - Prohibited acts. (a) Except as otherwise authorized by the state law or the exceptions in this division: (1) No person knowingly directly or through another person shall furnish, cause to be furnished or permit any person in such person's employ to furnish any alcoholic beverages to any person under 21 years of age; (2) No person under 21 years of age shall purchase or knowingly possess any alcoholic beverages; (3) No person under 21 years of age shall misrepresent such person's age in any manner whatever for the purpose of obtaining illegally any alcoholic beverages; (4) No person knowingly or intentionally shall act as an agent to purchase or acquire any alcoholic beverages for or on behalf of a person under 21 years of age; or (5) No person under 21 years of age shall misrepresent his identity or use any false identification for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining any alcoholic beverage. (b) The prohibitions contained in subsections (a)(1), (2) and (4) of this section shall not apply with respect to the: (1) Sale, purchase, or possession of alcoholic beverages for consumption for medical purposes pursuant to a prescription of a physician duly authorized to practice medicine in this state or at a religious ceremony. (2) Possession of alcoholic beverages for consumption by a person under 21 years of age when the parent or guardian of the person under 21 years of age gives the alcoholic beverage to the person and when the possession is in the home of the parent or guardian and such parent or guardian is present. (3) Sale of alcoholic beverages by a person when such person has been furnished with proper identification showing that the person to whom the alcoholic beverage is sold is 21 years of age or older. Sec. 4-50. - Conduct not prohibited by this division. If such conduct is not otherwise prohibited in this Code or by state law, nothing contained in this division shall be construed to prohibit any person under 21 years of age from: (1) Dispensing, serving, selling, or handling alcoholic beverages as a part of employment in any licensed establishment; (2) Being employed in any establishment in which alcoholic beverages are distilled or manufactured; or (3) Taking orders for and having possession of alcoholic beverages as part of employment in a licensed establishment. Sec. 4-51. - Violations; penalties. (a) Any person violating any provision of this article shall be subject to penalties as set forth in section 1-15, except as otherwise provided in this section. (b) Whenever any person who has not been previously convicted of any offense under this article or under any other federal or state law relating to alcoholic beverages pleads guilty to or is found guilty of a violation of section 4-49(a) or (b), the municipal court, without entering a judgment of guilt and with consent of such person may defer further proceedings and place him on probation upon such reasonable terms and conditions as the court may require. (c) The terms of probation shall preferably be such as to require the person to undergo a comprehensive rehabilitation program (including, if necessary, medical treatment), not to exceed three years, designed to acquaint him with the ill effects of alcohol abuse and to provide him with knowledge of the gains and benefits which can be achieved by being a good member of society. (d) Upon the violation of a term or condition of probation, the court may enter an adjudication of guilt and proceed accordingly. (e) Upon fulfillment of the terms and conditions of probation, the court shall discharge such person and dismiss the proceedings against him. Discharge and dismissal under this subsection shall be without court adjudication of guilt and shall not be deemed a conviction for purposes of the section or for purposes of disqualifications or disabilities imposed by law upon conviction of a crime. Discharge and dismissal under this subsection may occur only once with respect to any person. Sec. 4-52. - Use of citations authorized for certain violations. (a) Unless the officer has reasonable cause to believe that such person is intoxicated, a law enforcement officer may arrest by issuance of a citation a person accused of violating only section 4-49(b). (b) The citation shall enumerate the specific charges against the person and either the date upon which the person is to appear and answer the charges or a notation that the person will be later notified of the date upon which the person is to appear and answer the charges. (c) Nothing in this section shall be construed to invalidate an otherwise valid arrest by citation of a person who is intoxicated. (d) A law enforcement officer arresting a person by the issuance of a citation under this section may require any such person having a driver's license or instruction permit to deposit said license or permit with the arresting officer in order to ensure the appearance of such person to answer the charges against him. The procedures and rules connected with the acceptance of such license or permit and subsequent disposition of the case shall be the same as provided for the acceptance of a driver's license as bail on arrest for traffic offenses pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 17-6-11. Sec. 4-53. - Transfer to county misdemeanor jurisdiction. Any person charged with a first offense violation of this article shall be entitled upon request to have the case against him transferred to the court having general misdemeanor jurisdiction in the county in which the alleged offense occurred. Secs. 4-54—4-79. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - LICENSING[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Declaration of business of manufacturing, selling and other dealings in alcoholic beverages as privilege subject to regulatory requirements, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-1; powers of local authorities as to granting, refusal, suspension or revocation of licenses generally, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2; allowing or permitting of breaking of packages or drinking of contents thereof on premises prohibited, exception for sales pursuant to a license for consumption on the premises, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-26.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 4-80. - License declared privilege. Notwithstanding anything in this article to the contrary, the distribution, sale, handling, and other dealing in or possession of alcoholic beverages in the city is a privilege and not a right, and the issuance of a license under this chapter shall not create any property rights in the license holder. Furthermore, such privilege shall not be exercised in the city, except as licensed under the terms of this chapter. State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-1. Sec. 4-81. - License required. No malt beverage, wine, distilled spirits or any other alcoholic beverage shall be sold or manufactured in the city, except under a license issued under this chapter by the city clerk's office. State Law reference— Dealing in malt beverages at wholesale and retail prohibited without local license, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40; county licensing fees for the sale of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-41; restriction on county licensing fees for the sale of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-43; dealing in wine at wholesale and retail prohibited without local license, O.C.G.A. § 3-8-40. Sec. 4-82. - Compliance with applicable law required. The requirements of this chapter shall be in addition to any other requirements for business licenses under this Code and if other provisions of this Code conflict with this chapter, then this chapter shall control. In addition, all licensees shall at all times comply with federal and state laws, municipal ordinances and the rules and regulations of the state revenue commissioner, including licensing qualifications. Sec. 4-83. - Classification of licenses. Licenses that may be issued under this chapter include:
Sec. 4-84. - Separate license required for each business location. A separate alcoholic beverage license shall be required for each retail place of business licensed under this chapter. Sec. 4-85. - Payment of other taxes required for license issuance. No license shall be issued under this chapter unless the applicant has fully paid all license fees and taxes due under this chapter as well as all other business taxes and ad valorem taxes, and any utility billings due to the city for the business location. Sec. 4-86. - Qualifications for licensure. No alcoholic beverage license shall be granted to any applicant, unless that applicant meets the following qualifications, in addition to all other requirements of this chapter: (1) All applicants must be at least 21 years of age at the time of filing an application for license under this chapter. (2) All applicants for retail licenses must provide with the application for license proof of financial responsibility. The city clerk may require all applicants to provide financial statements and other evidence of financial responsibility in conjunction with any application. (3) The applicant must be a citizen of the United States or a resident alien, and a resident of the county for a period of one year preceding the date of filing the application, except as otherwise specifically provided in this section; provided, however, that county residency requirements may, at the discretion of the city clerk, be waived if the applicant designates a resident of the city or county who shall be responsible for any matter relating to the license. (4) No applicant who has a criminal record (except minor traffic offenses) shall be granted a license. The plea of nolo contendere and the forfeiture of bond or collateral shall be considered a conviction for the purposes of this subsection. Additionally, no applicant who has been convicted of violating any ordinance of the city or any law or regulation of the state or any political subdivision thereof, governing the sale of any alcoholic beverage shall be granted a license. (5) No license shall be issued to an applicant who has previously had revoked, within five years next preceding his application, any license issued to him by any city or county in this or any other state to sell alcoholic beverages of any kind. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-009, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-87. - Moral character of applicant and employees. (a) All applicants for alcoholic beverage licenses must be of good character, and all managers, clerks or other employees shall be of like character or the application will not be considered. (b) Ascertainable standards of good moral character of the applicant that may be considered by the city clerk in deciding if a license will be issued include, but are not limited to, the following: (1) Present and prior compliance with city ordinances. (2) Prior supervision over employees and customers. (3) Truthfulness in submitted application. (4) Criminal and civil court records. (5) Employment history. Sec. 4-88. - Active involvement in business required. (a) Applicants for license and licensees under this chapter shall be either the owner of the premises for which the license is held or the owner of a lease thereon, and a copy of any applicable premises lease shall be provided with the license application. If the applicant is a franchisee, then such applicant shall attach a copy of the franchise agreement or contract with the application. (b) The applicant for a license under this chapter must be active in and solely responsible for the management and operation of the business for which the license is granted. Sec. 4-89. - Partnership applicants. If the applicant is a partnership, all members of the partnership must be qualified to obtain a license, one member of the partnership must be a resident of the county, and all members of the partnership must make sworn statements of those qualifications. Sec. 4-90. - Corporate applicants. A license may be granted to a corporation existing under the law of the state or to a foreign corporation authorized to do business in the state; provided, however, that any such corporation shall be required to designate a resident of the county as its local agent responsible for compliance with all the requirements of this chapter and authorized to accept all services of notice. Secs. 4-91—4-108. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - APPLICATION PROCEDURE
Sec. 4-109. - Application contents. All applications for licenses, both originals or renewals, must be accompanied by a full and complete statement under oath, of information relative to any and all interest in establishments that sell at wholesale or retail malt beverages or wine, for consumption on or consumption off (package) the premises. This shall include: (1) The names and addresses of all persons interested in the ownership of the business applying for a license to sell malt beverages, together with an interest each person or any member of his immediate family has in any other business licensed to sell malt beverages or wine; (2) The ownership of the land and building where the business is to be operated; also, location of building; (3) The amount of rental paid for the land and building and the manner in which the rent is determined and to whom and at what intervals it is paid; (4) The names and addresses (by affidavit from the owner, lessor, or sub-lessor of the land and building) of all persons having any whole, partial, beneficial, or other interest in and to the land and building on and in which the licensed establishment is located; (5) A set of fingerprints of all persons with any interest in the ownership of the business, which in the case of a corporation shall be deemed to mean a set of fingerprints for the corporate officers and manager of the proposed business. These fingerprints must be processed through and found negative by the Georgia Crime Information Center (GCIC) and the National Crime Information Center (NCIC); (6) Photograph of all persons with any interest in the ownership of the business, which, in the case of a corporation, this shall be deemed to mean a photograph of all corporate officers and the manager of the proposed business location; and (7) A certified check on a bank in this state, or cash, in the amount of the fixed license fee. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-010, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-110. - Fees. All fees associated with licensure under this chapter shall be in the amount established by the city council. Sec. 4-111. - Notice of change in declared status. Any change in any relationship declared in the license application must be filed with the city clerk when the change is made, and failure to so file within a period of 30 days after the change is made, shall be grounds for license cancellation or revocation. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-010, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-112. - Investigation of applications. (a) Applicants, by filing for a license to sell malt beverages or wine, agree to furnish the data, information, and records as called for herein and also agree to submit under oath to interrogation by the city clerk, city attorney and mayor and council, or any of them, as to any facts considered pertinent to the application. Applicants, by filing the application, also agree to produce for oral interrogation by the city clerk, city attorney, and mayor and council, or any of them, any person requested by the city clerk, city attorney, and mayor and council, or any of them, as being important in the ascertainment of the facts relative to the granting of a license. Failure to furnish this data, information and records, or failure to produce these persons within 30 days from the date of the request by the city, shall automatically serve to dismiss with prejudice the application of the applicant failing to furnish the data, information and records or failing to produce these persons. (b) All applications for new licenses for sale of malt beverages or wine for consumption on the premises and applications for renewals thereof, shall be investigated by the city clerk and no new or renewal license shall be acted upon by the city clerk or issued by the city clerk until the city clerk has indicated in writing that in his opinion no violation exists upon the facts as stated and ascertained by the aforesaid investigation as to any state or city law in effect as of the date of the rendering of the opinion. (c) All applicants for new licenses or for transfers of locations shall be passed upon by the city clerk and his action shall be taken within 30 days from the date of the filing of the application or notice of location transfer unless written notice of extension by the city clerk is given one week prior to the 30-day deadline. (d) Any change in any relationship declared in the application for license or license renewal requires investigation by the city clerk prior to the issuance of a renewal license shall be passed upon by the city clerk within 30 days from the date of the filing of these changes. (e) The city clerk is specifically authorized and charged with the duty to issue a license under this chapter to each and every person who meets all the qualifications for the issuance of said license. The city council shall not review applications for sale of beer for consumption on the premises or renewal thereof, this duty having been specifically delegated to the city clerk. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-011, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-113. - Property survey. All applications shall include a certificate of the proposed business building and the straight line distance from the proposed business building and property line of the nearest school and nearest residential building, showing compliance with the appropriate provisions and section of this article. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-012, 2-14-1980) Secs. 4-114—4-139. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - RENEWAL AND TRANSFER
Sec. 4-140. - Term of license. No license under this chapter shall be issued other than from September 1 of one year until August 31 of the next year, and in case of the revocation or surrender of the license before expiration of the above term, the holder shall not be entitled to receive any refund of any fees or taxes whatsoever. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-013, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-141. - Lapse of license; application for extension. All businesses issued licenses under this chapter must, within 90 days after the issuance of a city license, open for business. Failure to open for business shall constitute forfeiture and cancellation of the issued licenses and no refund of license fees or business taxes shall be made. Any applicant unable to comply with the time limit of this section may make written request to the city clerk for an extension of time not to exceed 90 days, and the city clerk may, at his discretion, grant or deny the request. Sec. 4-142. - Renewal permitted; conditions. All alcoholic beverage licenses in this article may be renewed by payment of the fees set forth in the city fee schedule, provided that: (1) Applications for renewal of existing licenses are made in person by the applicants at the office of the city clerk between December 1 and December 15 of each year for the succeeding year and the prescribed license fee paid at time of filing. (2) The licensee and location remain the same. (3) The licensee's circumstances would enable him to qualify for a license if the renewal was a new application. (4) The licensee is still in compliance with the requirements of state and municipal laws and regulations pertaining to the original issuance of the license and pertaining to the operation of the business under the license at the time of application for renewal. (5) The city has received no complaints regarding the licensee's operation of the licensed premises. Sec. 4-143. - Effect of complaint on license renewal; complaint procedure. If a complaint is received as to the licensee's alleged violation of state or municipal law or regulation before December 31 of the licensed year or 30 days after the application for renewal is received, whichever date is later, the license shall not be renewed but shall be referred to the mayor and council for decision as to whether renewal shall be granted as follows: (1) The mayor and council shall conduct a hearing after giving the licensee reasonable notice of the time and place of such hearing, as well as the purpose thereof. (2) The licensee may remain open for business until a decision by the mayor and council is made and shall have a period of three days following that decision in which to pay the required fees, if the decision of the mayor and council is to permit renewal of the license. Sec. 4-144. - Transferability of license. (a) Licenses shall not be transferable, except as otherwise provided herein. In the case of the death of any person holding a license or any interest therein, the same may, in the discretion of the city clerk, be transferred to the administrator, executor, or the lawful heir of the decedent. The executor, administrator, or lawful heir, shall have a 30-day grace period to apply for a license transfer. (b) Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one or more partners in a partnership holding a license to withdraw from the partnership in favor of one or more partners who were partners at the time of the issuance of the license. (c) Should a transfer of location be approved, there shall be no pro rata return of any license fee or business tax and the new location shall be considered as a new license hereunder. (d) All applications for transfer of locations shall comply with the provisions herein set forth governing new licenses. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-014, 2-14-1980) Secs. 4-145—4-171. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - REVOCATION AND SUSPENSION
Sec. 4-172. - Investigations incident to disciplinary action. The city council shall have the right to make such inquiry or investigation as it may find to be reasonably necessary to determine the licensee's compliance or noncompliance with this chapter. Such investigation may consist, among other actions, of calling licensees for examination under oath, obtaining evidence under oath from other persons, the procurement of documents and records including records of the licensee, and inspection and examination of records and documents from whatever source obtainable. Sec. 4-173. - Effect of license denial by state. In the event the applicant is denied a license by the state, upon the proof of that refusal, he shall be entitled to a refund of the license fee or business tax less the investigative fee as required, and less an additional charge in the amount established by the city council to cover the clerical costs of granting the license. This refund may be made by the city clerk without the necessity of any action by the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-015, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-174. - Procedure for suspension or revocation. (a) Whenever the state shall revoke any permit or license, the city license to deal in that product shall immediately thereupon be automatically revoked without any action by the city clerk or mayor or council or any municipal officer. (b) Whenever a holder of a license granted in this article by the city clerk shall fail to open for business the establishment referred to in the license and begin the sale of products authorized by the license within nine months from the date of issuance of the license, or whenever a holder of a license shall begin the operation of a business and sale of the products as authorized in the license but shall fail to operate the business for a period of nine consecutive months, the holder shall automatically forfeit his license which shall be cancelled or revoked without the necessity of any further action by the city clerk or mayor or council or any other municipal officer. (c) Except as provided for herein, no license which has been issued or which may hereafter be issued by the city to any person, under this article, shall be suspended or revoked except for due cause as hereinafter defined and after a hearing and upon prior five days' written notice to the holder of the license of the time, place, and purpose of the hearing, and a statement of the charge upon which the hearing shall be held. The licensee shall have an opportunity at this hearing to respond to and challenge such charges, to present witnesses under oath, to confront and cross examine opposing witnesses under oath, and to have a verbatim written transcript made upon his own initiative and expense. (d) Due cause for the suspension or revocation of a license shall consist of the violation of any state or city law regulating the business or violation of regulations made pursuant to authority granted for the purpose of regulating the business or for the violation of any state or federal law, or for the violation of any provision of this Code, except traffic violations. (e) The hearing shall be conducted before the mayor and council by either or both the mayor and city attorney. (f) In the event of revocation, no refund or any portion of the license fee or business tax shall be returned. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-016, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-175. - Prevention of evasions; records; inspections. (a) Upon demand by the city clerk or the mayor and council, it shall be the duty of any licensee to throw open to these city officials or their designee, during regular business hours, all portions of the place of business for the purpose of enabling these city officials to ascertain and gain any information as may be necessary for determining the percentage of gross receipts from the sale of prepared food and the percentage of gross receipts from the sale of malt beverages. (b) Upon demand by these city officials, it shall also be the duty of any licensee to furnish the city officials during regular business hours at the licensee's place of business, all books of account, invoices, papers, reports, and memoranda containing entries showing amount of purchases, sale receipts, inventory and other information, from which the correct percentage of gross receipts from the sale of prepared food as opposed to malt beverages, including exhibition of bank deposit books, bank statements, copies of sales tax receipts to the state, copies of state income tax reports, and federal income tax reports. (c) It shall be the duty of any licensee of the city to secure, preserve, and maintain and keep for a period of three years, the records and documents enumerated and referred to in subsection (b) of this section. (d) It shall be unlawful for any licensee or for any servant, employee, or agent of the licensee to fail or refuse to perform any duty herein imposed upon the licensee or to obstruct or interfere with any city official in obtaining information necessary for determination of the aforesaid percentage of sales. (e) Except in the case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the license fee or business tax provided in this Code, it shall be unlawful for any officer, employee, agent, or clerk of the city or any person to divulge or make known in any manner the information required to be submitted in the registration and application of license, or otherwise submitted under the terms of this article and the rules and regulations promulgated in connection therewith. All information so submitted shall be confidential and open only to the officials, employees, agents, or clerks of the city using the information for the purpose of the administration of this chapter. Independent auditors or bookkeepers employed by the city shall be classified as employees. (f) Nothing herein contained shall prevent the disclosure of the license fee or business tax levied and assessed upon any person subject thereto, the name, addresses, and type of business of the license holder. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to prohibit publication by the city officials of statistics so classified as to prevent the identification of particular reports or returns on the items thereof or the inspection of the records by duly qualified employees of the federal or state tax departments. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-017, 2-14-1980) Secs. 4-176—4-203. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - APPEALS
Sec. 4-204. - Appeal of decision of clerk. The denial of issuance or renewal of any license under this chapter by the clerk may be appealed to the city council by filing notice with the clerk, who shall place the matter on the agenda for the council's next regular meeting following the clerk's receipt of the application for appeal. A clerk's suspension or revocation of a license issued hereunder may be appealed to the city council in the same manner. Sec. 4-205. - Appeal of decision of council. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city council on an appeal of the decision of the city clerk with regard to refusal to issue or renew a license or to suspend or revoke a license issued under this chapter shall be appealed to a court of competent jurisdiction in the manner provided by state law. Secs. 4-206—4-233. - Reserved. DIVISION 6. - EMPLOYEES
Sec. 4-234. - Restrictions regarding age, criminal history and beverage service. (a) Unless otherwise permitted by state law, no licensee shall employ in any premises used for the sale of alcoholic beverages, any person under the age of 18 years or any person who has been convicted in this or any state or by the United States or any other country of soliciting for prostitution, keeping a disorderly place, illegally dealing in narcotics, sex offenses, or any charge relating to the unlawful manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquors, or any other crime involving moral turpitude, within ten years immediately prior to the date of employment, and employment of such a person subjects the licensee to suspension or revocation of the license by the mayor and council. (b) Minors under 18 years old may be employed in or about places of business where malt beverages and wine are sold, provided the minor shall not be allowed or required to dispense, sell, deliver off-premises or take orders for malt beverages or wine, or any other alcoholic beverage, or in any manner aid or assist in the dispensing, sale, delivery off-premises or take orders for such beverages as per state law. (c) Malt beverages and wine by the drink shall be served only by employees of the establishment. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-019, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-235. - Other types of liquor prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person operating places licensed for the sale of malt beverages or wine to store or have therein any other alcoholic beverages for which he holds no license. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-022, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-236. - Copy of these provisions to be maintained on licensed premises. It shall be the duty of the licensee hereunder to maintain a copy of this chapter on the premises and to instruct each and every employee of the terms thereof. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-026, 2-14-1980) Secs. 4-237—4-265. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - ESTABLISHMENTS LICENSED FOR CONSUMPTION ON THE PREMISES
Sec. 4-266. - Restrictions on locations near private residences. No license for consumption of malt beverages or wine for consumption on the premises where sold shall be issued to any location that is within 75 feet of any private residence, that distance to be measured from the nearest point of the proposed business building to the nearest point of the residential building. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-005, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-267. - Licensure limited to restaurant establishments. Licenses for the sale of malt beverages or wine by the drink, for consumption on the premises licensed, shall be issued only to the applicants seeking licensure for restaurants, as that term is defined in this chapter. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-006, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-268. - Standards to determine seating capacity; compliance with fire regulations; inspections. If a minimum seating capacity is prescribed herein, the requirements shall be judged by existing city building, fire and technical codes as contained in this Code or state regulations. The fire department shall, upon request of the city clerk, inspect the premises and report its findings to the city clerk. All premises licensed hereunder shall conform at all times to all fire regulations of the city, county, and state. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-007, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-269. - Hours and days of operation. (a) No license holder under this article shall be allowed to sell malt and vinous beverages and wine between the hours of 12:00 a.m., Saturday, and 6:00 a.m., Monday, and between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. on other days, and shall not permit their places of business to sell malt beverages and wine on Sundays, and any other days prohibited by state law. Any license holder licensed for sale of malt beverages or wine for consumption on the premises shall close its business no later than one hour after midnight. (b) No license holder shall sell malt beverages or wine on Christmas Day. (c) The prohibition against the selling of malt beverages or wine to any person on election day shall apply only within the territorial boundaries for which the election day is being held. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-018, 2-14-1980; Ord. No. 82-10; Ord. of 8-13-2002(1); Ord. of 7-8-2003) State Law reference— Sale of alcoholic beverages on Sunday, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7; Sale of alcoholic beverages on Sundays and election days generally, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20; Sunday sales by farm wineries, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-21.2; Sunday sales of distilled spirits by private clubs, O.C.G.A. § 3-7-2. Sec. 4-270. - License number to be displayed. Each person licensed to sell malt beverages or wine for consumption on the premises where sold shall have printed on the front window, adjacent to the main entrance of the licensed premises, the inscription "City License No. ____________" in uniform letters, not less than three inches and not more than four inches in height. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-020, 2-14-1980) State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-3. Sec. 4-271. - Condition of premises. (a) All licensed premises shall be kept clean and in proper sanitary condition and in full compliance with the provisions and regulations governing the conditions of premises used for the storage and sale of food for human consumption. It shall be unlawful to permit any disturbance of the peace or obscenity or any lewd, immoral, or improper entertainment, conduct, or practices on the premises. (b) The fire department shall upon request of the city clerk and/or mayor and council, inspect each premises and report their findings to the same. All premises licensed hereunder shall conform at all times with all fire regulations of the city. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-021, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-272. - Certain coin-operated and mechanical devices prohibited. No licensee shall permit on his premises any slot machine, pinball machine or other machine of any kind or character operated for amusement purposes. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-023, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-273. - Music dispensing machines and cigarette vending machines permitted. (a) Machines or central systems used for musical entertainment are permitted; provided the machines or systems may be controlled by individual user or maintained by licensee in such a manner so as to ensure proper decorum at all times. Loud or otherwise abusive sounds are specifically prohibited. No sounds are permitted which would measure above an 80-db sound level as measured 50 feet from the building in any direction. (b) Coin-operated cigarette vending machines are permitted. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-024, 2-14-1980) Sec. 4-274. - Sales outside licensed premises prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any sale to be made outside of the building, premises, or place of business licensed for sales except as permitted herein. (Ord. No. 80-1, § 1-025, 2-14-1980) Secs. 4-275—4-296. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PACKAGE SALE ESTABLISHMENTS
Sec. 4-297. - Restrictions on locations near private residences. No license for the package sale of malt beverage or wine for consumption off the premises where sold shall be issued to any location which is within 75 feet of any private residence in the city, that distance to be measured from the nearest point of the proposed business building to the nearest point of the residential building in the city. (Ord. No. 80-2, § 80-004, 2-19-1980; Ord. of 4-18-2000) Sec. 4-298. - Hours of operation. (a) No holder of a license under this chapter for the package sales of malt beverages or wine for consumption off the premises where sold shall sell, give away or otherwise dispense malt beverages or wine for off-premises consumption between the hours of 12:00 a.m., Saturday, and 6:00 a.m., Monday, and between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on other days, and shall not permit the place of business to be open for the sale of malt beverages and wine on Sundays, and any other days prohibited by state law. (b) No license holder shall sell malt beverages or wine on Christmas Day. (c) The sale of malt beverages and wine is allowed on election day. (Ord. No. 80-2, § 80-014, 2-19-1980; Ord. of 8-13-2002(2); Ord. of 11-9-2004) State Law reference— Sale of alcoholic beverages on Sunday, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7; Sale of alcoholic beverages on Sundays and election days generally, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20; Sunday sales by farm wineries, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-21.2; Sunday sales of distilled spirits by private clubs, O.C.G.A. § 3-7-2. Sec. 4-299. - Sign with license number and prohibition of consumption on premises to be displayed. Each person licensed to sell malt beverages and wine for off-premises consumption shall have printed on the front window adjacent to the main entrance of the licensed premises, the inscription "City License No. ____________ - Consumption of Beer, Malt Beverages, and Wine on Premises Strictly Prohibited." in uniform letters, not less than three inches and not more than four inches in height. (Ord. No. 80-2, § 80-016, 2-19-1980) State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-3. Sec. 4-300. - Condition of premises. (a) All licensed premises shall be kept in clean and in proper sanitary condition and in full compliance with the provisions and regulations governing the conditions of premises. It shall be unlawful to permit any disturbance of the peace or obscenity, or any lewd, immoral or improper entertainment, conduct, or practices on the premises. (b) The fire department shall upon request of the city clerk or mayor and council, inspect each premises and report their findings to the same. All premises licensed hereunder shall conform at all times with all fire regulations of the city. (Ord. No. 80-2, § 80-017, 2-19-1980) Secs. 4-301—4-318. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - EXCISE TAXES[4] Footnotes: --- (4) --- State Law reference— Local excise taxes on malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80; excise taxes on malt beverages to be paid by wholesale dealer, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-81; prohibition on requirement for markings on beverage containers regarding excise taxes, O.C.G.A. § 35-5-82; local excise taxes on wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-8-60.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 4-319. - Malt beverage and wine excise tax levied. (a) There is hereby levied and imposed upon all wholesale dealers selling malt beverages within the city a specific excise tax in the following amount:
(b) Each wholesale dealer selling malt beverages and wine within the city shall file a report by the tenth day of each month showing for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities of malt beverages, by size and type of container, constituting a beginning and ending inventory for the month; sold within the city. Each such wholesale dealer shall remit to the city on the tenth day of the month next succeeding the calendar month in which such sales were made, the amount of excise tax due in accordance with this article. (c) No decal, stamp, or other identifying marking shall be required on malt beverages sold within the city. (Code 1999, § 3-501; Ord. of 5-15-1973, § 1) State Law reference— Imposition of excise tax on malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80; imposition of excise tax on wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-60; imposition by municipalities of excise tax on distilled spirits package sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-80; imposition by municipalities of excess taxes on distilled spirits sold by the drink, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-130. Sec. 4-320. - Taxes collected upon delivery. (a) It shall be unlawful for any retailer of alcoholic beverages to receive and retain these beverages, unless he shall have paid the tax thereon. (b) It shall be unlawful for any wholesaler of alcoholic beverages to sell or deliver these beverages to any retailer thereof unless he shall concurrently with this delivery collect the tax imposed. (c) It shall be unlawful for any wholesaler of alcoholic beverages to fail to remit to the city when promptly due, the taxes levied, and collected by the wholesaler. It shall be unlawful for any person engaged as a retailer of these beverages to receive these beverages from another retailer unless the tax has been paid. (d) It shall further be unlawful for any retailer of alcoholic beverages to receive and retail these beverages from another retail store, regardless of whether the other store shall be owned by the receiving retailer, or regardless of whether the other store is located within the corporate limits of the city, unless the tax shall have been paid and remitted to the city clerk. Secs. 4-321—4-343. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 4-344. - Examination of books and records. The books and records of all wholesalers selling or delivering these beverages and all retailers thereof in the city shall be subject to inspection and audit by the agents of the city to Ensure compliance herewith. It shall be unlawful for any person to deny to any authorized agent of the city reasonable access to its books and records and shall be the duty of each person to keep accurate records of payments and collections of the tax and remittances. Sec. 4-345. - Unpaid taxes. Alcoholic beverages on which city taxes have not been paid are subject to seizure and may be destroyed or sold by public sale, as provided by law. Sec. 4-346. - Authority to require reports. In administration of this chapter, the city council may require the filing of reports by any person having in the person's possession or custody information relating to sales of beverages that are subject to taxation under this chapter. The reports shall be filed with the license division, department of finance, when required, and shall set forth the price charged for each sale, the dates of sales, and the other information as may be required. Sec. 4-347. - Confidentiality. (a) Any person having an administrative duty assigned by the city council under this article shall not make known in any manner the business affairs, operations or information obtained by an audit of books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any licensee or any other person visited or examined in the discharge of official duty. (b) Any person having an administrative duty assigned by the city council under this article shall not make known the amount of source of income, profits, losses, expenditures or any particular thereof set forth or disclosed in any return or permit any return or copy thereof or any book containing any abstract or particulars thereof to be seen or examined by any person not having the administrative duty under this subdivision, except for judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the tax levied and assessed. (c) Successors, receivers, trustees, executors, administrators, assignees and guarantors, if directly interested, may be given information as to the items included in the measure and amount of unpaid tax or amounts of tax required to be collected, interest and penalties. Sec. 4-348. - Deficiency determinations. (a) Computation. If the city and the city's designee are not satisfied with the return of the tax levied under this subsection or the amount of the tax levied under this subsection required to be paid to the city by any person, the city may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information within the city's possession or that may come into the city's possession. One or more than one deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more than one monthly period. (b) Interest on deficiency. The amount of the determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month or any fraction of a month from the tenth day after the close of the monthly period for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment. (c) Offsetting of overpayments. In making a determination, the administrator may offset overpayments, for a period, against underpayments, for another period, against penalties and against the interest on underpayments. (d) Notice of deficiency determination. The city and the city's designee shall give to the licensee written notice of the city's deficiency determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail; if by mail, the service shall be addressed to the licensee at the licensee's address as it appears in the records of the licensee division, department of finance. For service by mail or any notice required by this subsection, the service is complete at the time of deposit in the United States post office. (e) Time limits. Except for a fraud, intent to evade this section or authorized rules or regulations or failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the tenth day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period shall last expire. Sec. 4-349. - Determination if no return made. (a) Estimate of gross receipts. If any licensee fails to make a return for the tax levied under this subdivision, the administrator shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the licensee or, as the case may be, of the amount of the total sales in this city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period in respect to which the licensee failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information that is or may come into the possession of the administrator. Upon the basis of this estimate, the administrator shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid by the city, adding to the sum thus determined a penalty equal to 15 percent thereof. One or more determinations may be made for one or for more than one period. (b) Offsets; interest. In making a determination, the mayor or the mayor's designee may offset overpayments for a period or penalties and against the interest on the underpayments. The interest on underpayments shall be computed in the manner set forth in subsection (c) of this section. (c) Interest on amount due. The amount of the determination, exclusive of penalties, shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month or any fraction of a month from the tenth day after the close of the monthly period for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned, until the date of payment. (d) Notice. Promptly after making a determination, the administrator shall give to the person written notice to be served personally or by mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice of a deficiency determination. Sec. 4-350. - Collection of unpaid tax. (a) Action for collection. At any time within three years after any tax levied under this article or any amount of tax required to be collected under this article become due and payable and at any time within three years after the delinquency of any tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the administrator may bring an action in the courts of this state or any other state or of the United States in the name of the city to collect the amount delinquent together with penalties and interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. (b) Duties of successors or assigns. If any licensee liable for any amount under this article sells or terminates the business, the licensee's successors or assigns shall withhold sufficient of the purchase price to cover the amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the license division, department of finance, showing that the amount has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. (c) Liability for failure to withhold. If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold purchase price as required, the purchaser becomes personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by the purchaser to the extent of the purchase price, valued in money. Within 30 days after receiving a written request from the purchaser for a certificate, the license division of the department of finance shall either issue the certificate or mail notice to the purchase at the purchaser's address as it appears on the records of the license division, department of finance, of the amount that must be paid as a condition of issuing the certificate. The time within which the obligation of a successor may be enforced shall start to run at the time the operator sells the business or at the time that the determination against the operator becomes final, whichever event shall last occur. Sec. 4-351. - Overpayments. If the amount of any tax, penalty or interest has been paid more than once or has been erroneously collected or received by the city under this subdivision, it may be offset as provided in herein. If the operator or person determines that the person has overpaid or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the administrator, the person will have three years from date of payment to file claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which claim is founded. The claim shall be audited. If the claim is approved, the excess amount paid the city may be credited on any amounts due and payable from the person by whom it was paid or the person's successors. Sec. 4-352. - Supplementary to license fee. The excise tax provided for in this article shall be in addition to any license fee, tax or charge which may now or in the future be imposed upon the business of selling malt beverages or wine at retail or wholesale, within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1999, § 3-502; Ord. of 5-15-1973, § 2) Sec. 4-353. - Penalties for late, false or fraudulent reports. (a) The failure to make a timely report and remittance shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to 25 percent of the total amount due during the first 30-day period following the date such report and remittance were due and a further penalty of 25 percent of the amount of such remittance for each successive 30-day period or any portion thereof, during which such report and remittance are not filed. (b) The filing of a false or fraudulent report shall render the wholesale dealer making such report liable for a penalty equal to 25 percent of the amount of the remittance which would be required under an accurate and truthful report. (Code 1999, § 3-503; Ord. of 5-15-1973, § 3) Secs. 4-354—4-380. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT
Sec. 4-381. - Findings and purpose. (a) Based on the demonstrated experience of other urban counties and municipalities, including but not limited to: Atlanta and Fulton County, Georgia; DeKalb County, Georgia; Orlando, Florida; Orange County, Florida; Indianapolis, Indiana; Los Angeles, California; Beaumont, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; St. Paul, Minnesota; and Austin, Texas, which experience is found to be relevant to the problems that face the city, the mayor and council of the city take note of the notorious and self-evident conditions and secondary effects attendant to the commercial exploitation of human sexuality, which do not vary greatly among the various communities within our country, particularly the problems of crime, blight, and deterioration which are brought about by alcohol and live nudity. (b) It is the finding of the mayor and council of the city that public nudity (either partial or total) under circumstances related to the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages in so-called nude bars or establishments offering so-called nude entertainment or adult entertainment in conjunction with the sale of alcoholic beverages, begets criminal behavior and tends to create undesirable community conditions. (c) Among the acts of criminal behavior found to be associated with nudity and alcohol are disorderly conduct, prostitution, public indecency and drug trafficking. Among the undesirable community conditions identified with the concentration of adult entertainment establishments are depreciation of property values in neighborhoods surrounding nude bars or adult entertainment establishments where alcoholic beverages are sold, increased expenditure for and allocation of law enforcement personnel to preserve law and order, increased burdens on the judicial system as a consequence of the criminal behavior hereinabove described, and acceleration of community blight by the concentration of adult establishments in particular areas. (d) Other negative effects which were found by the mayor and council are the apparent connection of these establishments to organized crime and illegal drug sales; the potential spread of communicable diseases to law enforcement personnel who answer calls at adult establishments and to patrons of such establishments; and the potential proliferation of adult entertainment establishments after the initial siting of an adult entertainment establishment in a particular neighborhood. (e) The city, therefore, finds that it is in the best interest of the health, welfare, safety, and morals and preservation of its businesses, neighborhoods, and of churches, schools, and parks to prevent the adverse impact of adult entertainment establishments. Therefore, the city finds that the prohibition of live nude conduct in establishments licensed to serve alcohol for consumption on the premises is in the public welfare by furthering legitimate government interests, such as reducing criminal activity, protection against property devaluation and deterioration, and eliminating undesirable community conditions normally associated with establishments which serve alcohol and allow and/or encourage nudity, and that such prohibition will not infringe upon the protected constitutional rights of freedom of speech. To that end, this section is hereby adopted. Sec. 4-382. - Conduct prohibited; exception. The following types of entertainment, attire and conduct are prohibited upon any premises licensed to sell, serve or dispense alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises within the city: (1) The employment or use of any person live, in any capacity, in the sale or service of alcoholic beverages or food while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing, as to expose any portion of his specified anatomical areas. (2) Live entertainment where any person appears unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose any portion of his specified anatomical areas or where such person performs acts of specified sexual activities or acts which simulate specified sexual activity. (3) The holding, promotion, sponsoring or allowance of any contest, promotion, special night, event or any other activity where live patrons of the licensed establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the conduct prescribed in subsections (1) and (2) of this section. Sec. 4-383. - Liability of licensee for conduct of persons in licensed premises. It shall be unlawful for a licensee to permit any conduct prohibited in this article that he knows or has reasonable cause to know is taking place on the premises. Any such conduct by a licensee shall be a violation of this Code and shall be punishable as provided in section 1-15 and shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of any license issued under this chapter. (Ord. No. 80-2, § 80-001, 2-19-1980)

div.head: Chapter 6 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority of cities and counties to restrict adult bookstores, explicit media outlets, and adult movie houses to certain areas, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-3; state regulation of coin-operated amusement machines, O.C.G.A. § 48-17-1 et seq.; state regulation of billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-1 et seq.; authority of city to regulate billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-2; state regulation of carnivals, circuses and itinerant entertainers, O.C.G.A. § 43-1-15.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Area of operation means the territory located within the corporate limits of the city. Billiard room means any public place where a person is permitted to play the game of billiards and for which a charge is made for use of equipment. Billiards means any of the several games played on a table surrounded by an elastic ledge of cushions with balls which are impelled by a cue and shall include all forms of the game known as "carom billiards," "pocket billiards," and "English billiards." Public dancehall means any place where public dancing is conducted where the music is provided either by what is commonly known as a "jukebox" or other mechanical means or by musicians or disc jockeys and whether or not a charge is made for participants or whether a collection is taken therefor. Sec. 6-2. - Licensing and occupation taxes. Except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, the provisions of chapter 12, Business Taxes and Regulations, shall apply to all business entities in the city, including those referred to in this chapter. If this chapter and the business regulation chapter conflict, the more stringent provision shall prevail. Secs. 6-3—6-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BILLIARD ROOMS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Regulation of operators of billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-1 et seq.
Sec. 6-23. - Qualification of license applicants. No license to operate a billiard room shall be issued to any person who is not 21 years of age and a citizen of the United States or who has been convicted of a felony. Sec. 6-24. - Application to clerk for license. Before any person shall be authorized to conduct a billiard room in the city, that person must, in addition to complying with this article, make application to the clerk of such municipal corporation for a license. Sec. 6-25. - Filing of affidavit with application. Every application for a license shall be accompanied by the affidavit of the applicant, sworn to before an officer authorized by law to administer oaths, stating: (1) That the applicant is a citizen of the United States; (2) That he has not been convicted of a felony; (3) That he will not permit vagrants or persons under the influence of intoxicating liquors to enter or play in his place; (4) That the applicant will have personal charge and management of the business; (5) That he will not permit gambling nor permit the billiard tables to be used in any manner other than provided by law. Sec. 6-26. - Transfer of ownership of licensed room. If any licensee shall voluntarily relinquish personal supervision, management and control of such billiard room, he shall surrender his license to the city council, who may issue a new license to some other person to continue the business under this article, in which event credit shall be given for the unused portion of the surrendered license; but, if any licensee transfers or subleases the place of business to anyone or relinquishes management and control of the business without surrendering his license to the city council for reissuance, the license shall be deemed to be forfeited, and the city council must notify the chief of police, who shall close the place of business. Sec. 6-27. - License fees. The city council shall fix a license fee for the operation of such billiard rooms and make such additional regulations governing its operation as the city may deem proper. Sec. 6-28. - Sanitary premises required. All public billiard rooms shall be kept in a clean, sanitary condition, and shall comply with all sanitary rules and regulations of the board of human resources of the county board of health or city department of health having jurisdiction. Sec. 6-29. - Use of obstructions and enclosures. No person who operates a billiard room shall permit any screens, curtains, blinds, partitions, or other obstructions to be used to prevent a clear view of the interior, which clear view must be maintained at all times. No partitions forming rooms, stalls, or other enclosures shall be permitted; however, this section shall not be construed to prohibit the maintenance of washrooms and toilet rooms for proper purposes nor maintenance of closets for storage purposes exclusively. Sec. 6-30. - Hours for operation. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a billiard room between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m., or to permit any person to remain in such billiard room between such prohibited hours, except regular employees performing necessary labor on the premises. Sec. 6-31. - Gambling, posting of sporting results; sale or use of alcoholic beverages. (a) No dice, cards, dominoes, or other games of chance shall be permitted, nor any form of gambling allowed, in any billiard room or in any other business place operating in connection therewith; and such games as Kelly Pool, Keno Pool, Pigeon Pool, Parker Pool, Star Pool, Scrub Pool, and similar gambling devices, are prohibited. No racing or other betting pool shall be exhibited or sold in such places of business. The use of baseball tickers and the posting of results of sporting events is expressly prohibited in billiard rooms or in any place operating in connection therewith. (b) No alcoholic beverages shall be sold, served, or allowed to be used in or on the premises or billiard rooms or any place operating in connection herewith, except in conformity with O.C.G.A. § 43-8-12. Sec. 6-32. - Connections with gambling houses. It shall be unlawful for any billiard room to maintain connections with any place where gambling is conducted or where persons congregate for the consumption of alcoholic beverages or for immoral purposes. Sec. 6-33. - Inspection by law enforcement authorities; reporting and prosecuting violations. It shall be the duty of the police or other constituted authorities to inspect all public billiard rooms in the city for the purpose of ascertaining whether or not the provisions of this article are being observed; and it shall be his and their duty to report all violations promptly to the appropriate prosecuting attorney and furnish him with such information and assistance as is necessary for the prosecution of such violations. Sec. 6-34. - Applicability to religious orders, charitable institutions, and clubs. This article shall not apply to billiard tables or billiard rooms operated by private industrial concerns, Young Men's Christian Associations, religious orders, charitable institutions, state, county, or city institutions, fraternal orders, or bona fide clubs using such tables for members or employees only. Secs. 6-35—6-56. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - DANCEHALLS[3]

No dancehall shall be operated or conducted in a residential section of the city or within 500 feet of a residence. (Code 1999, § 6-409(b); Ord. of 9-18-1951) Sec. 6-59. - Applicability of provisions to individual dancehalls and those combined with other establishments. The provisions of this article shall apply to any such dancehall whether conducted separately or in connection with any other business.
