It shall be unlawful for any person, in association or agreement with one or more persons, to assemble, congregate, or meet together in the vicinity of the premises of another, or upon the streets, approaches, or places adjacent thereto, for the purposes of inciting a riot or for the purpose of violating the rights of any citizen of the city defined under federal, state, or city law or for the purpose of prohibiting the exercise of any right defined thereunder. State Law reference— Unlawful assembly, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-33; inciting to riot, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-31. Secs. 36-102—36-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC HEALTH AND MORALS
Sec. 36-131. - Public indecency. It shall be unlawful for any person to perform any of the following acts in a public place: (1) An act of sexual intercourse; (2) A lewd exposure of the sexual organs; (3) A lewd appearance in a state of partial or complete nudity; or (4) A lewd caress or indecent fondling of the body of another person. State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-8. Secs. 36-132—36-164. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - OFFENSES INVOLVING DRUGS AND ALCOHOL
Sec. 36-165. - Marijuana possession. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess marijuana in the city where prohibited by state law. The city shall prosecute persons found to be in unlawful possession of one ounce or less of marijuana. State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 16-13-30(j). Sec. 36-166. - Drinking in public places. Except as expressly permitted by state law or this Code, it shall be prohibited for any individual or group of individuals to drink or publicly display alcoholic beverages, including beer, openly on a city street or alley or in an automobile or vehicle on the city streets or alleys, and it is further prohibited for an individual or group of persons to drink or display any alcoholic beverages, including beer, on the grounds of any private property within the city limits, so as to disturb the peace and dignity of passersby, owners of businesses, or customers of business establishments. (Code 1999, § 6-1009; Ord. of 6-16-1970) Sec. 36-167. - Public drunkenness. It shall be unlawful for any person to be and appear in an intoxicated condition in any public place or within the curtilage of any private property not his own other than by virtue of the owner or lawful occupant, which conditions are made manifest by boisterousness, intoxicated condition or act or by vulgar, profane, loud or unbecoming language. State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. Secs. 36-168—36-187. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - MINORS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 36-188. - Unlawful purchases for minors. No person in the city shall procure for any minor any article which the minor is forbidden by law to purchase. (Code 1999, § 7-108) Sec. 36-189. - Air rifles, etc. No parent or guardian shall allow his child or ward to shoot any kind of BB gun, pellet gun, or similar apparatus. (Code 1999, § 6-1015; Ord. of 4-15-1958) Secs. 36-190—36-216. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - CURFEW
Sec. 36-217. - Applicability; exceptions. It is unlawful for any minor 17 years of age or younger to loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon or be upon public streets, sidewalks, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or any place unsupervised by an adult over the age of 18 years having lawful parental authority over such minor or an adult who is the lawful guardian of such minor, between the hours of 12:00 midnight on any day and 5:00 a.m. of the following day; and provided that the provisions of this section shall not apply in the following instances: (1) When a minor is accompanied by his parent, guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of the minor; (2) When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by his parent or guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of such minor; (3) When the minor is returning directly home from a school activity or entertainment, and school sponsored or school-related events, including recreational activities or dances; (4) When the minor is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the above-referenced places during the prescribed period of time; (5) When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of First Amendment rights of speech, freedom of assembly or free exercise of religion; (6) When the minor is in a motor vehicle with parental consent or the consent of the lawful guardian for normal travel with interstate travel through the city excepted in all cases from the curfew; (7) When the minor is on the property of the building in which he resides. Sec. 36-218. - Parental responsibility for compliance; penalties. (a) It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other person having custody or control of any child 17 years of age or younger to permit or by insufficient control to allow such child to be in violation of this division. (b) Upon conviction of this section for the first time, a person shall be given a warning by the court. Such warning shall be entered on the court records for filing. Second and subsequent violations shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-15. (Ord. No. 96-14, 8-13-1996)

div.head: Chapter 38 - PARKS, RECREATION AND CULTURAL AFFAIRS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— City and county recreation systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq.; gifts of public parks or pleasure grounds to municipality, O.C.G.A. § 36-37-1; park and recreation boards, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-5; establishment of city and county supervised recreation, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-3; political subdivisions to have environmental testing on property acquired for park or recreational area, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-18.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 38-1. - Applicability; joint city-county recreation areas. This chapter shall be applicable to all Cochran/Bleckley Recreation Areas, which is a term applied to properties owned, operated or leased by the city and county jointly to provide recreational facilities for their citizens. The joint recreation areas specifically include, but are not limited to, property of the Bleckley County Board of Education made available to the city and county pursuant to an agreement with the board of education. Sec. 38-2. - Use of recreational facilities constitutes privilege. The use of recreational facilities provided by the city is a privilege, and not a right, and such use shall be conditioned upon compliance with the provisions of this article and all other provisions of this Code and other city ordinances. The city reserves the right to limit access to its recreational facilities to such days and times as it deems appropriate and to exclude certain individuals from the use of such facilities as provided in this chapter. Secs. 38-3—38-24. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - USE RULES AND REGULATIONS
Sec. 38-25. - Powers and duties of mayor and council. The mayor and council shall conduct and supervise public playgrounds, indoor recreation centers, and other recreational facilities owned or controlled by the city and the joint city-county recreation areas. They may conduct or sponsor any form of recreational or cultural activity that will employ the leisure of the people in a wholesome or constructive manner. They may conduct such activities on properties under their control, on public properties with the consent of the authorities thereof, and on private properties with the consent of the owners. (Code 1999, § 5-201) Sec. 38-26. - Permit for use of park for group activities. (a) Whenever any association or organization desires to use park facilities for a particular purpose, such as picnics, parties or theatrical or entertainment performances, a representative of said association or organization shall first obtain a permit from the city for such purposes. The city council may adopt an application form to be used for such situations. (b) Applications for a permit under this section shall be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount established by the city council. (c) The city shall grant the application if it appears that the association or organization will not interfere with the general use of the park by the individual members of the public and if the association or organization meets all other conditions contained in the application. The application may contain a requirement for an indemnity bond to protect the city from any liability of any kind or character and to protect city property from damage. (Code 1999, § 5-203(c)) Sec. 38-27. - Requirements for use of facilities by independent leagues. All independent leagues using city-county recreational facilities shall: (1) Establish rules governing the conduct of players, coaches, and spectators while attending or participating in recreational activities in city-county recreational areas in a form acceptable to the city and county and post or otherwise distribute rules to all participants. (2) Report any violations of city, county or leagues rules, policies, or regulations to the recreation director or designate within 24 hours of occurrence with a written report by league officials within 72 hours of occurrence. (Ord. of 3-1-2002, § VI) Sec. 38-28. - Use and maintenance of picnic areas. No person in the park shall: (1) Picnic or lunch in a place other than those designated for that purpose. Attendants shall have the authority to regulate the activities in such areas when necessary to prevent congestion and to secure the maximum use for the comfort and convenience of all. Visitors shall comply with any directions given to achieve this end. (2) Use any portion of the picnic areas or of any of the buildings or structures therein for the purpose of holding picnics to the exclusion of other persons, nor shall any person use such area and facilities for an unreasonable time if the facilities are crowded. (3) Leave a picnic area before the fire is completely extinguished and before all trash in the nature of boxes, papers, cans, bottles, garbage, and other refuse is placed in the disposal receptacles where provided. If no such trash receptacles are available, then refuse and trash shall be carried away from the park area by the picnicker to be properly disposed of elsewhere. (Code 1999, § 5-203(d)) Sec. 38-29. - Merchandising; advertising and signs. No person in a park shall: (1) Offer for sale any article or thing, nor shall he station or place any stand, cart, or vehicle for the transportation, sale or display of any such article or thing. (2) Announce, advertise, or call the public attention in any way to any article or service for sale or hire. (3) Paste, glue, tack, or otherwise post any sign, placard, advertisement, or inscription whatever, nor shall any person erect or cause to be erected any sign whatever on any public lands or highways or roads adjacent to a park. Exceptions to this section may be made as to any regularly licensed concessionaire acting by and under the authority and regulation of the city. (Code 1999, § 5-206) Sec. 38-30. - Damage to park property and littering prohibited. No person in a park shall: (1) Willfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, or displace or remove, any building, bridges, tables, benches, fireplaces, railings, paving or paving material, waterlines, or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, signs, notices or placards whether temporary or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts, or other boundary markers, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever either real or personal. (2) Fail to cooperate in maintaining restrooms and washrooms in a neat and sanitary condition. (3) Throw, discharge, or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the waters of any fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or other body of water in or adjacent to any park or any tributary, stream, storm sewer, or drain flowing into such waters, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of said waters. (4) Have brought in or shall dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage, or refuse, or other trash. No such refuse or trash shall be placed in any waters in or contiguous to any park, or left anywhere on the grounds thereof, but shall be placed in the proper receptacles where these are provided; where receptacles are not so provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence, and properly disposed of elsewhere. (Code 1999, § 5-202) Sec. 38-31. - Speed of vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in any park in excess of 15 miles per hour. (Code 1999, § 5-205) Sec. 38-32. - Profanity and violence at city-county recreational facilities. The following are prohibited acts: (1) Profanity or profane language that is sufficient to constitute a verbal attack on coaches, players, spectators, or sports officials. (2) Physical threats to coaches, players, spectators or sports officials. (Ord. of 3-1-2002, § III) Sec. 38-33. - Exclusion of certain individuals from recreational facilities. (a) Upon joint determination by the mayor, city council and the sole commissioner of Bleckley County: (1) Any person who is convicted of a violent misdemeanor or felony at a recreation facility shall be excluded from participating in or attending any recreation event or activity at city-county recreation facilities for a minimum period of two years or for the term of any sentence or probation service imposed by any court deciding a particular case, whichever is greater. (2) Any person who is convicted of using profanity or profane language sufficient to constitute a verbal attack or of making physical threats to coaches, players, spectators or sports officials in or in connection with any city-county recreational facility shall be excluded from participating in or attending any recreation event or activity at city-county recreation facilities for a minimum period of six months. This section is specifically, but not exclusively, applicable to members of independent leagues using city-county recreational facilities. (3) Any person charged with a misdemeanor involving violence or any felony may, on recommendation of the recreation director and a finding by him of aggravated circumstances, be excluding from participating in or attending any recreation event or activity at city-county recreational facilities pending the outcome of the criminal proceedings against him. (4) Any person excluded from participating or attending any recreation event or activity at city-county recreation facilities for any period of time that is found to have violated the exclusion shall be permanently banned from participating in or attending any recreation event or meeting at city-county recreational facilities. In addition, any person violating an exclusion under this section shall be subject to arrest and other penalties as provided in section 1-15. (b) The city council and the sole commissioner of Bleckley County shall have sole authority for the enforcement of suspension and reinstatement of park use privileges. (Ord. of 3-1-2002, § IV) Sec. 38-34. - Reinstatement of park use privileges. Upon joint determination of the mayor, city council and the sole commissioner of Bleckley County: (1) At the conclusion of the period of exclusion as set out in section 38-33(a)(4), an individual excluded from participating in or attending any recreation event or activity at city-county recreation facilities may petition the board to have that individual's exclusionary status lifted. The city and county governing authorities, when considering a petition for lifting the exclusionary status, shall consider the nature and severity of the crime committed and shall not be obligated to lift the exclusionary status of any individual who, in the opinion of the city and county, pose a threat to the safety and health of citizens using the joint recreation facilities. (2) Any person who petitions and his exclusionary status is continued by the board may petition again at the end of a one-year period for permission to attend and participate in events and activities at city-county recreation facilities. (3) Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as obligating the city-county designated officials to lift a person's exclusion from participating or attending recreation events and activities at city-county facilities and, in appropriate cases, the exclusion may be permanent. (Ord. of 3-1-2002, § V)

div.head: Chapter 40 - PEDDLERS, ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND SOLICITORS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.; municipal and county ordinances for issuance of permits to charitable organizations for solicitation of contributions on streets and highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-97.1; charitable solicitations, O.C.G.A. § 43-17-1 et seq.; transient merchants, O.C.G.A. § 43-46-1; municipal and county occupation taxes for certain traveling salespersons, merchants, and dealers, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-354.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 40-1. - Definitions. For the purposes of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings specified: Itinerant merchant means any person, regardless of whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, and regardless of whether a resident of the city, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares, and merchandise within the city, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses, or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad box car, boat, or public room in any hotel, lodginghouse, apartment, or shop within the city for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares, and merchandise, either privately or at public auction. Peddler means any person, regardless of whether a resident of this city, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle, or any other type of conveyance from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying, or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden produce, farm products, or provisions who offers and exposes the same for sale, or who, without traveling from place to place, sells or offers the same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance. Secs. 40-2—40-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LICENSING
Sec. 40-21. - License required. Each peddler and itinerant merchant who does business within this municipality shall be required to obtain a license from the city clerk in the manner specified in this chapter. This section does not apply to charitable solicitors. Sec. 40-22. - Application for license. Application for a license under this article shall be made as provided in chapter 12, except that such application shall contain the following additional information: (1) The fingerprints of the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business, or in lieu thereof at least three letters of recommendation from reliable property owners in the county in which the business is to be conducted, certifying as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or other evidence which establishes the good character and business responsibility of such person to the satisfaction of the mayor and council; (2) The places in the city where it is proposed to carry on applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that the business shall be conducted; (3) The places, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant, where applicant within the six months next preceding the date of the application conducted a transient business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address of any building or office in which such business was conducted; (4) A statement of the nature, character, and quality of the goods, wares, or merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by the applicant in the city; the invoice value and quality of such goods, wares, and merchandise; where the goods or property to be sold are manufactured or produced; and where such goods or products are located at the time the application is filed; (5) A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers, and, if required by the city clerk, copies of all the advertising whether by handbills, circulars, newspaper advertising, or otherwise, shall be attached to the application; and (6) A statement of whether the person having the management or supervision of the applicant's business have been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor, or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense, and the punishment assessed therefor. Sec. 40-23. - Bond. (a) Before any license shall be issued for engaging in a transient or itinerant business as provided in this article, the applicant for such license shall file with the city clerk a bond running to the city in the amount established by resolution of the city council executed by the applicant, as principal, and two sureties upon which service of process may be made in the state. (b) The bond to be approved by the city attorney, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all of the provisions of the ordinances of this city and the statutes of this state regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares, and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of the ordinances or statutes, or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him by any person for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with such applicant, whether the misrepresentations or deceptions were made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents, or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares, and merchandise sold or any part thereof. (c) Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use of the aggrieved person. Such bond must be approved by the city attorney, both as to form and as to the responsibility of the sureties thereon. Sec. 40-24. - Registered agent for service of process. (a) Before any license as herein provided shall be issued for engaging in business as a peddler or itinerant merchant in this municipality, the applicant shall file with the city clerk an instrument nominating and appointing the city clerk his true and lawful agent with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and on behalf of applicant in respect to any matters connected with or arising out of the business transacted under the license and the bond, or for the performance of the conditions of the bond, or for any breach thereof. (b) The instrument shall also contain recitals to the effect that the applicant for the license consents and agrees that service of any notice or process may be made upon the agent, and when so made shall be taken and held to be as valid as if personally served upon the person applying for the license, according to the law of this or any other state, and waiving all claim or right of error by reason of such acknowledgment of service or manner of service. (c) Immediately upon service of process upon the city clerk, as herein provided, the city clerk shall send to the licensee at his last known address, by registered mail, a copy of the process. Sec. 40-25. - Administrative and license fee. Each application for license under this article shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable administrative fee to defray, in part, the city's costs in processing the application. In addition, each application for license under this article shall be accompanied by a business license fee in the sum established by resolution of the city council. Sec. 40-26. - Duty to exhibit license. All persons obtaining a license under the provisions of this article shall be required to exhibit such license at the request of any citizen. Sec. 40-27. - Noise restrictions. No licensee under this article, nor anyone in his behalf, shall shout, make any outcry, blow a horn, ring a bell, or use any other sound device including any loudspeaking radio or amplifying system upon any of the streets, alleys, parks, or other public places of the city or upon any private premises in the city where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom capable of being plainly heard upon the streets, avenues, alleys, parks, or other public places for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods, wares, or merchandise that the licensee proposes to sell. Secs. 40-28—40-57. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SOLICITORS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 40-58—40-112. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PRIVATE NOTICES
Sec. 40-113. - Right of citizens to refuse or consent to solicitation. The owner or occupant of any residential, commercial, industrial or other property or structure within the city shall have the right to refuse solicitation as provided in this division. Sec. 40-114. - Notice regulating solicitation. Notice of the determination by the occupant of giving invitation to solicitors or the refusal of invitation to solicitors to any structure shall be given as provided in this section by posting a weatherproof card or sign, exhibited on or near the main entrance door to the structure, indicating the determination by the occupant to invite or reject solicitation. The solicitation card or sign, exhibited as provided herein, shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence or other structure of the information contained thereon. Sec. 40-115. - Duty of solicitors. It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going onto any premises in the city to first examine the notice, if any is attached, and be governed by the statement contained on the notice. If the notice states that solicitation is refused, then any solicitor, whether registered or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. Further, any solicitor who has gained entrance to any structure, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by the occupant. Sec. 40-116. - Effect of prohibited solicitation; violations and penalties. It is unlawful and shall constitute a violation of this Code and a nuisance for any person to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting, in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of this division. Any person violating this division shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-15 and, in addition, revocation of any registration entered under this chapter.

div.head: Chapter 42 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Downtown development authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-42-1 et seq.; municipal business improvement districts, O.C.G.A. § 36-43-1 et seq.; redevelopment authority of municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-44-1; city and county development authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.; county and municipal urban development, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-1 et seq.; city and county zoning procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; local zoning proposal review procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-67-1 et seq.; conflicts of interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.; coordinated and comprehensive planning and service delivery by counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 42-1—42-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - INTERGOVERNMENTAL LAND USE DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 42-19—42-39. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LAND USE DISPUTE RESOLUTION PROCEDURE
Sec. 42-40. - Purpose and intent; adoption of similar provisions by city and county. The governing authorities of the city and Bleckley County have found it necessary, desirable, and in the public interest to establish a formal process for resolving land use disputes as they relate to property annexation and land use plans. This article is intended to establish that process and, to that end, the city and county have adopted similar provisions. Sec. 42-41. - Procedure. (a) Prior to initiating any formal annexation activities, the municipality will notify the county of a proposed annexation and provide information on location of property, size of area, and proposed land use or zoning classification, if applicable, of the property. (b) Within 30 days following receipt of the information required in subsection (a) of this section, the county will forward to the city a statement indicating that the county has no objection to the proposed land use for the property or describing its bona fide objection to the city's proposed land use classification, providing supporting evidence, and listing any possible stipulations or conditions that would alleviate the county's objections. (c) If the county has no objection to the city's proposed land use or zoning classification, the city is free to proceed with the annexation. If the county fails to respond to the city's notice in writing within the deadline, the city is free to proceed with the annexation and the county loses its right to invoke the dispute resolution process, or object to land use changes after the annexation. (d) If the county notifies the city that it has bonafide land use classification objections, the city will respond to the county in writing within 30 days of receiving the county's objections by either: (1) Agreeing to implement the county's stipulations and conditions, thereby resolving the county's objection; (2) Agreeing with the county and stopping action on the proposed annexation; or (3) Disagreeing that the county's objections are bona fide, in which event the city will initiate a joint meeting of the respective governments to resolve the issue. (e) If the city initiates mediation, the city and the county will agree on a mediator, mediation schedule and determine participants on the mediation. The city and county agree to share equally any costs associated with the mediation. (f) An annexation proposal shall not be effective until any bona fide land use classification objections raised by the county are resolved pursuant to the dispute resolution process. (g) The final resolution of any recommendation of a land use classification will be accorded to the governing body considering the annexation. In cases of land use disputes not related to annexation proposals, the final resolution of a land use dispute will be accorded to the jurisdiction in which the subject property is located. Notwithstanding the provisions of this subsection, either local government entity may seek declaratory judgment in a court of proper jurisdiction pursuant to a land use decision.

div.head: Chapter 44 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1]
div.p: (RESERVED) Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Junk dealers, O.C.G.A. § 43-22-1; pawnbrokers generally, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130 et seq.; local regulation of pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. §§ 44-12-135, 44-12-136.

div.head: Chapter 46 - SIGNS
div.p: (RESERVED)

div.head: Chapter 48 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Solid waste management generally, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-9-1; hazardous waste management, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-79; local and regional solid waste plans, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1; tire disposal restrictions, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-40.1; yard trimmings and disposal restrictions, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-40.2; authorization for local government units to enforce collection of taxes, fees, or assessments for solid waste management, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-39.3; authority of local governments to adopt and enforce local regulations for the handling and disposal of solid waste, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-30.9; Litter Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-40; transporting garbage or waste across state or county boundaries pursuant to contract, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-16; Resource Recovery Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-63-1 et seq.; littering highways, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-249.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 48-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Authorized private receptacle is a litter storage and collection receptacle as required and authorized in the city. Garbage means animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, and residue of food and like matter, and similar items normally placed in household waste containers. Handbill means any printed or written matter, any sample, device, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature. Litter means garbage, refuse, and rubbish as defined herein and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as prohibited by law, tends to create a danger to public health, safety, and welfare. Park means a park, playground, beach, recreation center or any other public area in the city, owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation. Private property means any dwelling, house, building, or other structure, designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building, or other structure. Public place means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds, and buildings. Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, and solid market and industrial wastes. Rubbish is nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as, paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, and similar materials. Trash means items resulting from normal cleaning activities of residential houses, such as clothing, toys, furniture, magazines, newspapers, cardboard boxes, and like matter. Vehicle means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. Yard waste means items resulting from normal maintenance of residential or business yards, including shrubbery, hedge clippings, grass clippings, leaves, vines, limbs, and like matter. (Ord. of 1995, § 1.0) Sec. 48-2. - Fines for violation of chapter. The following fines shall apply to violations of this chapter. Fines for violations not listed in this section shall be as provided in section 1-15, unless otherwise specifically provided in other sections of this chapter:
(Ord. of 1995, § 18.0) Sec. 48-3. - Administration responsibilities by mayor, council, and department heads. (a) The mayor will report to council at least once each year as to the problems encountered regarding solid waste, and whether the city should consider changes to improve administration. Report should address changes in laws covering solid waste generation, collection, and disposal, relationship of the city to the landfills receiving city refuse, economic changes in costs to collect and deposit in landfill, condition of city equipment, and longterm health of the solid waste department as to revenue generation. (b) The city clerk shall report at least once each year as to the applicability of city rates for collection and disposal of refuse, and will break such information down into commercial revenue and costs, and household revenue and costs. Report will show clearly whether the solid waste department has adequate revenue to operate properly, or whether losses are occurring or are anticipated, and whether rates should be changed in response to conditions that exist. A comparison of charges by the city with other cities in the area, including Perry, Warner Robins, Hawkinsville, Eastman, and Dublin, will be presented at the June council meeting, preceding the adoption of the annual budget for the next fiscal year. (c) The solid waste department chief will be responsible to identify conditions that violate this chapter, post warnings at the appropriate sites, and cause citations to be issued to residents holding this chapter in contempt; shall identify problems with solid waste collection and disposal and present them to the mayor and council for consideration; shall be solely responsible for the maintenance and care of city equipment used to collect and dispose of refuse; shall advise the mayor and council of improvements and efficiencies that should be adopted; and shall present a detailed and coherent report to the mayor and council at the June council meeting, preceding the adoption of the budget for the next fiscal year, and each year following that. (d) The council will oversee the collection and disposal of refuse and amend this chapter as appropriate, and will enforce the provisions of this chapter as required by its oath of office. (Ord. of 1995, § 19.0) Secs. 48-4—48-24. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 48-25. - Authority to collect and dispose of solid waste. (a) The city has exclusive right to collect and dispose of all garbage, trash, and yard waste defined as acceptable for city collection. (b) The city has authority to license industrial and institutional generators of solid waste to directly contract for removal and disposal. (c) The city has authority to oversee all refuse collection and disposal, including those items herein described as not acceptable for collection and disposal in the city solid waste collection system. (d) The city may furnish garbage, trash, and yard waste collection services outside the city limits if such enterprise improves the resource base and productivity of city operations. (e) No person, except authorized employees of the city or their authorized representatives, shall empty garbage, trash, or yard waste containers or receptacles, or collect, convey, or transfer garbage, trash, or yard waste, or other refuse through the street, alleys, or public thoroughfares of the city without a written permit granted and issued by the city. (Ord. of 1995, § 2.0) Sec. 48-26. - Garbage containerization requirements. (a) All customers of the city solid waste collection system will use commercial compactors, dumpsters, or automated refuse collection carts provided by the city. (b) All household customers shall place garbage in the container provided by the city. Occasional overflow is allowed, provided such overflow is properly bagged and placed at curb or street-side so as not to interfere with automated pickup of the container. (c) All commercial customers of the city will specify their actual container requirements to the city and shall have an appropriate compactor, dumpster, or one of several sizes refuse collection containers provided. All garbage shall be placed in such containers, and the containers shall be placed in the exact location specified by the city to facilitate pick-up. (d) All commercial customers shall not exceed the capacity of containers provided for the collection of garbage. No overflow is allowed. Generation of waste beyond the capability of the container may be cause for the city to refuse to collect, as well as result in a violation of this chapter. (Ord. of 1995, § 3.0) Sec. 48-27. - Placement of garbage for collection; frequency of pickups. (a) Garbage containers shall be placed consistently in one location for collection. The location will be identified by the city. (b) Garbage shall be physically separated from trash and yard waste to permit easy access by city garbage collection vehicles. (c) Garbage shall normally be collected once weekly. Pickup will occur on the same day and at approximately the same time each week for commercial and household customers. Normal collection days will be according to route schedules for each address. Equipment failure or other unforeseeable circumstances may alter schedules. Holidays observed by city workers will alter the pick-up schedule for the week in which the holiday occurs, and an alternate pickup schedule will be available at city hall. (d) Additional pickups may be scheduled for commercial customers who generate large volumes of garbage. The city will develop a schedule to meet individual business requirements and will charge the same fee for each pickup. (Ord. of 1995, § 4.0) Sec. 48-28. - Collection of trash and yard waste. (a) Yard waste and trash will be limited to three cubic yards for each week for each household or business as a rule. (b) The city shall not collect more than one load at any one location per week. A load is defined as one trailer load, or approximately 20 cubic yards. This is an absolute maximum and is an exception to the rule defined in subsection (a) of this section that should occur only on rare occasions. (c) Trash and yard waste shall be separated and placed in two distinct piles adjacent to the street, but not in the street. Placement will be between the sidewalk and street where sidewalks are provided. Waste may be placed on property near the street when available and when sidewalks are not available. Leaves may be mixed with regular yard waste for collection or placed in a separate pile in a manner that will not obstruct drainage, sidewalks, or street traffic. Leaves and other yard waste may not be bagged. (d) Cardboard boxes shall be collapsed and bundled. (e) Limbs shall not exceed six inches in diameter and shall not exceed four feet in length. (f) Loose debris, other than yard waste, shall be placed in a sealed, disposable container. Loose debris includes such items as packing materials, Styrofoam peanuts and similar items that would blow away and litter the neighborhood, if not kept in a container. (g) Grass clippings shall not be bagged and shall be separated from trash as previously stated. Grass clippings may be piled with other organic matter, such as hedge clippings and similar yard waste. (h) People living outside the city limits must not put garbage in either household or commercial containers owned by the city. Significant fines will be imposed for violators of this provision. (i) Household garbage will not be placed in commercial containers. A fine may also be imposed by the city for violation of this section. (j) The city will contribute all available resources to the collection and disposal of yard waste caused by severe storms and other acts of God or natural disaster. (Ord. of 1995, § 5.0) Sec. 48-29. - Refuse not acceptable for collection. (a) No leaves, limbs, or other trash placed on vacant lots by the property owner or other persons shall be collected. The city shall remove such waste, properly prepared and located if the owner requests such services and pays a pickup fee, in the amount established by the city council, for one time pickup, and the volume does not exceed the limit established herein for a single-family household. The fee shall be considerably more for larger volumes of refuse. (b) Dirt, or plant roots containing dirt, shall not be collected. (c) Limbs cut and placed near the street for collection by any person other than the resident of the property will not be collected or hauled by the city except as subsequently specified. If the owner or responsible person hires a person or business entity to perform work that results in limbs or other yard debris, the city will not remove the resulting waste. The person hired must remove the debris. (d) The resident of a property, or the owner of a business, on which trees over six inches in diameter are cut down whether by owner or any other persons, is required to promptly (within seven days) remove or have removed from the property at his own expense, all the limbs, logs, trunks, and tops and other debris resulting therefrom. (e) Construction materials and automotive parts are not acceptable for collection by the city. No construction or demolition materials such as bricks, concrete blocks, wooden boxes, lumber, roofing, sheetrock, masonite, or similar materials or automotive parts such as car hoods, fenders, grills, tires, axles, motors, transmissions, car frames, and similar materials shall be collected by the city. (f) No carpet shall be collected by the city. (g) Dangerous materials or substances, such as poisons, acids, caustics, infectious materials, batteries, explosives, paint, solvents, pesticides, herbicides, paint removers, petroleum products, petroleum by-products, etc., will not be collected by the city. Hazardous waste is defined as materials which may be toxic, easily flammable, explosive, reactive, or having toxic characteristics which could threaten public health, property, or the environment. (h) The collection of heavy dead animals, such as cows, horses, mules, etc., is not included in the services provided by the city. The owner or person having charge thereof will dispose of same in the manner and by the method directed by the city. The owner will be responsible for paying all charges. (i) Materials not prepared for collection in accordance with regulations and rules shall not be collected by the city. (j) Ashes will not be collected by the city. (k) Barbershops, beauty salons, pet grooming salons, etc., shall not receive collection for discarded hair, unless the same is packaged in closed plastic bags and placed inside authorized garbage containers. (Ord. of 1995, § 6.0) Sec. 48-30. - Disposal of industrial waste. The collection of wastes resulting from manufacturing, assembling, processing, and other industrial operations, waste oils, and other similar materials from garages and filling stations, and accumulation from packing houses, killing and dressing establishments, and wholesale fruit and vegetable houses shall not be included in the services provided by the city. Such premises or places shall dispose of same at their own expense in the manner and method directed by the landfill superintendent or appropriate state and local laws. (Ord. of 1995, § 7.0) Sec. 48-31. - Construction sites and standards of cleanliness. (a) The property owner and/or contractor in charge of a construction site shall furnish litter containers for construction and workmen litter. All litter from construction activity or any related activities shall be containerized and all litter will be picked up and placed in containers by workers at the end of each work day. (b) Rocks, waste building materials, and other refuse resulting from building or remodeling operations or resulting from general clean up of vacant or improved property just prior to occupancy will not be collected by the city. (c) All such litter and waste shall be removed by the building contractor, owner, or occupant of the building at his own expense. (Ord. of 1995, § 8.0) Sec. 48-32. - Owner's responsibility for cleanup costs. (a) The owner, occupant, or lessee of all property is required to remove all litter and place same in a proper container for collection. Vacant lots, borders, parking lots, embankments, parking lots, storage lots, fences, walls, and sidewalks are to be kept free of litter. Parking lots, shopping centers, convenience stores, drive-in restaurants, and all commercial and industrial enterprises will ensure that no litter remains on their property. (b) The city may remove litter from property where the owner/tenant refuses to do so and assess the cost for the cleanup against the property owner. Unmowed, trashy, littered yards or landscapes may be cleaned if the city determines such a need and does not get response in a timely manner from the owner/resident. A fine may be imposed in addition to actual cleanup costs. (Ord. of 1995, § 9.0) Sec. 48-33. - Items not acceptable for city owned containers. The following items shall not be disposed of in city provided containers, including, but not limited to, dumpsters, automated carts, and similar containers, nor will containers be emptied by the city until such items are removed: (1) Household or industrial appliances. (The city will remove white metal household appliances if property placed by your automated refuse cart.) (2) Furniture. (3) Tires, paint, solvents, or other chemicals. (Tires may be taken to the county land fill by the owner and disposed of with the owner paying a disposal fee.) (4) Wooden crates. (5) Logs and limbs. (6) Bed springs. (7) Rock, dirt, or concrete blocks. (8) Mattresses. (9) Liquids, wet garbage, food scraps, etc., of any type not sealed in appropriate containers. (10) Construction materials, including roofing materials. (11) Ashes and burned materials. (12) Yard debris, including grass clippings. (13) Hypodermic needles, hospital and medical waste, infectious or toxic substances (potentially or actually). (Ord. of 1995, § 10.0) Sec. 48-34. - Installation of compactors. (a) The city will review and approve all plans and specifications for the installation of compactor units to be used in connection with containers to this section. Such compactors will be approved by the city prior to installation being made. All compactor shredders and compactor containers shall be installed on class A, 3,000-pound-per-square-inch concrete pads of not less than a six-inch thickness. All such installations shall comply with the requirements of the building code of the city, the fire prevention code, and other safety laws and ordinances of the mayor and council. The city is authorized to adopt regulations as may be necessary with reference to such matters. (b) Compactors will be served by the city's authorized representatives. (Ord. of 1995, § 11.0) Sec. 48-35. - Assistance for the handicapped and disabled customers. (a) The following provisions are made for any resident who cannot use automated refuse carts provided the following requirements are met: (1) Handicapped, disabled, or elderly/feeble resident must live alone or all persons living at that household must also be disabled. (2) Disability forms provided by the city must be completed by the resident's physician and returned to the city. If more than one person lives in the household, disability forms must be completed for each person living therein. (b) If the requirements pursuant to subsection (a) of this section are not met, an automated refuse cart will be delivered to the resident and regular service will be provided by the city. (c) The city will provide special service to those residents who meet this requirement, provided that such residents help by placing their household refuse near the front or side of their home in an easily reachable location, and provided that the refuse is contained in closed, durable plastic bags. Refuse must be placed for collection by 7:30 a.m. on the designated collection days. (Ord. of 1995, § 16.0) Sec. 48-36. - Fees for collection and disposal of refuse and billing. Fees for garbage collection shall be in the amount established by the city council from time to time. (Ord. of 1995, § 17.0; Ord. No. 06-10, 10-10-2006) Secs. 48-37—48-60. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - AUTOMATED REFUSE CARTS
Sec. 48-61. - Issuance and use of city refuse carts. (a) Initially, the city will issue an automated refuse cart to each occupied residence on each automated route at no charge. The cart is the property of the city and shall not be removed from the address if the resident should move. A cart identification number will be assigned to the resident's utility account. (b) The cart shall only be removed from the property by duly authorized personnel of the sanitation department. (c) If the cart is stolen, the resident shall report the theft to the police department and the sanitation department. After receipt of the police report, the sanitation department will replace the automated cart at minimal charge to the resident. (d) The sanitation department is tasked to maintain automated carts in good working condition upon notification by the customers that repairs are needed. (e) If one automated cart is not sufficient for the household garbage generated, additional carts may be requested from the sanitation department. The fee will be the current basic sanitation rate times the number of carts issued to each address. (f) Each residence must have its own garbage container. Sharing of containers by multiple residences is not permitted. (g) Commercial customers using automated refuse carts will not allow any other business or household to use their containers. (h) Abuse of city-owned containers may result in a fine. (Ord. of 1995, § 12.0) Sec. 48-62. - Placement and frequency of collection. (a) Automated refuse carts shall be placed immediately adjacent to the street for collection only on designated collection days. (b) Carts shall be placed at the proper location for collection by 7:30 a.m. on designated collection days and shall be removed from the street by 7:00 p.m. on the same day. A written notice may be issued which may result in a fine for noncompliance with this chapter. After one written notice is issued to remove a cart from the street, a fine in the amount set by the city council will be imposed for any subsequent violations of this requirement. (c) Carts shall not be placed within four feet of any obstacle, such as, mailboxes, trash, trees, yard waste, white metal appliances, carts in driveway, etc. (d) Carts shall be placed no more than three feet away from the street. (e) Carts shall be placed with the identification number facing the street. (f) Cars parked on the street must be at least 50 feet away from the cart. (g) Carts shall be serviced once each week, except in some instances when a holiday occurs and the city provides an alternate schedule for pick-up, which will normally be in the paper beforehand and will always be available at city hall. Equipment failure may also alter the schedule. (h) Unless this section is complied with, the city may not provide service to the container. (Ord. of 1995, § 13.0) Sec. 48-63. - Acceptable refuse for automated refuse carts. (a) Garbage may be placed in automated refuse carts if properly prepared and deposited as defined herein. (b) Refuse may be placed inside an automated refuse cart provided that such trash fits inside the cart without hindering the free flow of refuse from the cart when it is emptied. (c) An automated cart shall not be overfilled so that the lid does not close properly. If there is overflow garbage, on rare occasions, properly bagged and placed next to the automated refuse cart but no closer than four feet from any obstacle, such as, mailboxes, trash, trees, yard waste, white metal appliances, carts in driveway, etc. (Ord. of 1995, § 14.0) Sec. 48-64. - Refuse not acceptable for automated refuse carts. Items enumerated in this chapter as unacceptable for city containers shall not be placed in a refuse cart. A container containing unacceptable refuse shall not be emptied until such time as the items are removed from the cart. A fine in the amount set by the city council shall be imposed on any person violating this section. (Ord. of 1995, § 15.0) Secs. 48-65—48-119. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - LITTERING
Sec. 48-120. - Litter in public places. No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the city except in public receptacles, in authorized private receptacles for collection. (Code 1999, § 6-702) Sec. 48-121. - Placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevent scattering. Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. (Code 1999, § 6-703) Sec. 48-122. - Sweeping litter into gutters prohibited. No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. (Code 1999, § 6-704) Sec. 48-123. - Merchant's duty to keep sidewalks free of litter. No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying places of business within the city shall keep the sidewalk in front of their business premises free of litter. (Code 1999, § 6-705) Sec. 48-124. - Litter thrown by persons in vehicles. No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the city, or upon private property. (Code 1999, § 6-706) Sec. 48-125. - Truck loads causing litter. No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place. Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley or other public place, mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter or foreign matter of any kind. (Code 1999, § 6-707) Sec. 48-126. - Litter in parks. No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city except in public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere as provided herein. (Code 1999, § 6-708) Sec. 48-127. - Litter in lakes and fountains. No person shall throw or deposit litter into any fountain, pond, lake, stream, or any other body of water in a park or elsewhere within the city. (Code 1999, § 6-709) Sec. 48-128. - Throwing or depositing handbills in public places. No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any sidewalk, street or other public place within the city. (Code 1999, § 6-710) Sec. 48-129. - Litter on occupied private property. No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property. (Code 1999, § 6-711) Sec. 48-130. - Owner to maintain premises free of litter. The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter. Provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection. (Code 1999, § 6-712) Sec. 48-131. - Litter on vacant lots. No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property within the city whether owned by such person or not. (Code 1999, § 6-713)

div.head: Chapter 50 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS, AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal authority to grant right to erect obstructions in streets, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-10; enclosures of lanes or alleys, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-11; municipal street improvements, 36-39-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 50-1—50-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - USE AND MAINTENANCE
Sec. 50-19. - Obstructing view at intersections prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any property owner or occupant to have or maintain on his property any tree, hedge, billboard, or other obstruction which prevents persons driving vehicles on public streets or alleys from obtaining a clear view of traffic when approaching an intersection. (Code 1999, § 6-1001) Sec. 50-20. - Banners and signs across streets and alleys restricted. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or have placed any banner or sign across any public street or alley except when expressly authorized by the mayor. (Code 1999, § 6-1002) Sec. 50-21. - Obstruction of drainage ditches. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or cause the obstruction of any drainage ditch in any public right-of-way. (Code 1999, § 6-1003) Sec. 50-22. - Abutting occupants to keep sidewalks clean. The occupants of property abutting on a sidewalk are required to keep the sidewalk clean. Also, immediately after a snow or sleet, such occupants are required to remove all accumulated snow or ice from the abutting sidewalk. (Code 1999, § 6-1004) Sec. 50-23. - Encroachment by street coverings, awnings or other shelters. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to build or maintain within the fire limits of the city over or upon the sidewalks or streets of said city, within said limits, any shelter or sidewalk or street covering, which shall encroach upon said streets or sidewalks, which said shelter or sidewalk or street covering shall be supported from the ground by columns or otherwise. (b) No awning shall be built or maintained over the sidewalks of the city, within the fire limits, which shall approach nearer to the ground or pavement than seven feet; and no such awning shall be constructed without permit from the city council first obtained, upon application, giving details of construction. (c) Any party who shall build or maintain any shelter, awning, or covering in violation of this section shall be punished, as provided for in section 1-15. (d) In any case of violation of the provisions of this section, the city, through its officers, shall have the right to remove any shelter, awning, or covering built or maintained in violation of this section at the expense of the person responsible for such violation, where such person fails to remove such shelter, awning, or covering within five days after notice for removal shall be given by the city. (Code 1999, § 6-1011; Ord. of 11-21-1922) Sec. 50-24. - Defacing streets, sidewalks, and curbs. It shall be unlawful for any person to deface any public sidewalk, street, or curb in the city by painting any signs thereon, whether for commercial advertising purposes or not, or to walk or drive any vehicle upon or injure in any way any newly laid street, sidewalk, or curbing pavement while the same is guarded by a warning sign or barricade or is soft or newly laid. Sec. 50-25. - Riding on sidewalks. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride any horse or any vehicle on any city sidewalks. Any person violating this section shall be deemed guilty of disorderly conduct. Sec. 50-26. - Deposits and discharges. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit on any street or sidewalk any rubbish or any material that may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material, or any glass or other article that may do injury to any person, animal, or property. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or to allow to be discharged onto any public street or sidewalk any water or other fluid material containing objectionable material such as sewage, waste, milk, or other organic material. Thus, it shall be unlawful for anyone to wash automobiles on the city sidewalks. Sec. 50-27. - Private use. It shall be unlawful for any person to use any street, sidewalk, or other public place as space for the display of goods or merchandise for sale; or to write or make any sign or advertisement on any such pavement unless approved by the mayor. Sec. 50-28. - Burning leaves and rubbish. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to burn any leaves, paper, rubbish, or other substances upon any of the public streets, sidewalks, or alleys of the city. Sec. 50-29. - Barricades. Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk, or other public place shall maintain suitable barricades to prevent injury to any person or vehicle by reason of the work, which barricades shall be protected by a light at nighttime. Sec. 50-30. - Maintenance of property between street and sidewalk. (a) All persons who own real estate in the city which abuts upon any sidewalk which is paved shall be required to keep that portion of such sidewalk which lies between the property line and the curbline of the adjoining street, and upon which his real estate abuts, in good and smooth condition and free from growing weeds and other obnoxious and unsightly vegetation or other things which would mar or detract from the beauty and cleanliness of the street upon which their property abuts. (b) Any property owner who shall place or allow grass to grow upon the portion of sidewalk lying between the property line and the curbline of the street as aforesaid, and upon which his real estate abuts, shall keep such grass properly mowed and free from rubbish of all kinds. If such owners are not in the possession of their property, then this section shall apply to their tenants or those who have possession or control of the same. Sec. 50-31. - Reports of defects and obstructions. It shall be the duty of every city officer and employee who becomes aware of any defect or obstruction, or of any unlawful deposit or discharge, in or on any public street, alley, curb, sidewalk, or other public way of the city to report the same as soon as possible. Sec. 50-32. - Openings. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or maintain any opening or stairway in any public street, sidewalk, or alley without first obtaining a permit from the city clerk in the manner specified in this article. All such lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a suitable strong cover or railing approved by the street superintendent. Sec. 50-33. - Poles and wires. Any person or company which maintains poles and wires in the streets, alleys, or other public places of the city shall keep such wires and poles free and away from any nearby trees or shrubs in such places, and keep all such trees and shrubs properly trimmed, subject to the supervision of designated city official, so that no injury shall befall either the poles and wires or the shrubs and trees by their contact. Secs. 50-34—50-54. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS, CURBS AND GUTTERS
Sec. 50-55. - Costs shared by city and property owners. Upon petition as provided in this article, the city will pay one-half and the affected property owners shall pay one-half of the total cost of installation of sidewalks, curbs and gutters but only if adequate funds are in the treasury of the city to cover the city's portion of the cost of the project as determined by the city council. Sec. 50-56. - Proration of costs among property owners. Costs of construction shall be prorated among the affected property owners by taking one-half of the total of the improvement made and prorating the cost thereof on the property owners according to his frontage on the sidewalks and curbs and gutters so improved. Secs. 50-57—50-76. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC ASSEMBLY AND PARADES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 50-77. - Interference with traffic and the conduct of business. (a) No number of persons shall block any street, sidewalk, alley or entrance to any place of business in the city by congregating on any street, alley, sidewalk, or entrance to any place of business in said city in such number as to interfere with traffic or the conduct of business thereon and therein; not more than four persons shall congregate at any one point on Second Street from the First Baptist Church to Southern Railway Crossing with North Second Street, in any one block, either in the street or on either sidewalk along said street. (b) No number of persons shall congregate in any place of business in said city in such a number as will interfere with the conduct of business therein, nor shall any person remain in said place of business when requested by the owner, manager or person in charge thereof to leave the premises. (c) No person shall sit down or lie down in any street, alley, sidewalk, or place of business in said city. (d) No person shall fail or refuse to cease and desist from any such violation when ordered so to do by any peace officer, or the owner, manager or person in charge of any place of business in said city. (Code 1999, § 6-1010; Ord. of 9-3-1963) Secs. 50-78—50-97. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PARADES
Sec. 50-98. - Permit—Required; application. It shall be unlawful to hold any parade, demonstration or congregation of people on the streets, alleys and sidewalks of the city without first obtaining a written permit therefor from the state department of transportation, if it is to be held on a state highway, and from the city mayor and chief of police, if it is to be held on a city street. Before any such permit shall be granted, the person desiring to hold any parade, demonstration or congregation of people on said streets, alleys or sidewalks shall make written application to said city council for permit therefor and in such application it shall be stated the particular purpose of holding same, the number of persons to be engaged in same, the number and character of vehicles to be used in same, the place from which same shall start, the route to be taken and the end of same, together with the approximate time of holding such parade, demonstration or congregation, when the same shall start and when the same will end. (Code 1999, § 6-1005; Ord. of 9-3-1963, § 1) Sec. 50-99. - Same—Procedure for granting or denying. When a parade application is submitted, the mayor and chief of police shall consider same as to whether such activity applied for shall work an undue burden on the traffic and business of the city or shall block or interfere with business or traffic in the city. The mayor and chief of police shall grant or refuse same or fix the time of starting, the place of starting, the route to be followed, the end of same and the amount of time to be consumed in such activity. If the permit is granted by the mayor and chief of police, such activity shall proceed under the terms of the permit. If the permit is refused by the mayor and chief of police, no such parade, demonstration or congregation of people shall be held. (Code 1999, § 6-1006; Ord. of 9-3-1963, § 2) Sec. 50-100. - Conduct of parade; violations and penalties. Any parade, demonstration or congregation of people held in the city pursuant to a permit granted by the mayor and chief of police as herein provided shall be conducted in an orderly manner. In the event any such activity shall not be so conducted, the city shall immediately order the activity discontinued. Failure or refusal of any person engaged in such activity to disperse and cease when ordered to do so shall subject the person to penalties as provided in section 1-15. (Code 1999, § 6-1007; Ord. of 9-3-1963, § 3) Secs. 50-101—50-128. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - STREET ACCEPTANCE
Sec. 50-129. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to set minimum standards for streets and roadways to be accepted into the city road system so as to provide for the public economy, safety and orderly traffic flow and movement, and for other purposes. (Ord. of 1996, § I) Sec. 50-130. - Applicability. This article shall apply to streets and roads constructed and built by individuals and developers who propose to induce the city to accept such streets and roadways into the public transportation system of the city. This article shall not work to restrict the city from constructing its own roadways and streets in any instance and at any location wherein such construction is in the interest of the public and for enlarging, increasing or improving the flow of traffic and to provide needed accesses for ingress and egress for public purposes. (Ord. of 1996, § II) Sec. 50-131. - Factors considered by city in determining whether to accept streets. The city shall not automatically accept streets and roadways constructed in compliance with the minimum conditions provided for hereunder, unless it can be reasonably expected and shown that such streets will be utilized for public purposes. Such use will be of public significance and the acceptance of same will not work to defeat the public economy by requiring maintenance and upkeep in disproportionate amount to the public good created by such acceptance. (Ord. of 1996, § III) Sec. 50-132. - Affirmation of owner; dedication of property permanent. The owner of such property seeking to induce the city to accept same shall certify this conveyance to be his free act and deed and will dedicate same to the public use forever all such streets, alleys, and easements, without restriction or reversion. (Ord. of 1996, § III) Sec. 50-133. - Adequate description of streets and roadways. Any property so conveyed under the provisions hereof to the city shall be accompanied by a recordable plat depicting the finished streets and rights-of-way and at a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet, and which plat shall show, in case of a subdivision, the boundaries of said subdivision; the names of such streets or roadways; the names and record owners of any adjoining unplatted land in the case of a subdivision, the easements for public utilities; the location of existing roads or streets which adjoin or abut the streets or roadways proposed to be conveyed to the city, and those streets or roadways which extend to within 80 feet of the streets or roadways proposed to be conveyed to the city. (Ord. of 1996, § IV) Sec. 50-134. - Developer or subdivider responsible for paving. Any property conveyance to the city pursuant to this article shall be accompanied by a recordable plat depicting, at a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet: (1) The name and location of finished streets and rights-of-way. (2) The name and location of existing roads or streets that adjoin or abut the streets or roadways proposed to be conveyed to the city. (3) The name and location of those streets and roadways that extend to within 80 feet of the streets or roadways proposed to be conveyed to the city. (4) The location of all easements for public utilities. (5) If the property conveyed is located in a subdivision, the boundaries of the subdivision and the names of record owners of any adjoining unplatted land. No streets or roadways shall be accepted by the city unless same are paved at the time of such proposed conveyance to the city and which paving meets the minimum standards as provided for herein. The entire cost of such construction, grading, drainage, sloping, grassing, engineering, surveying and all other expense shall be at the sole cost and expense of such developer or subdivider. (Ord. of 1996, § V) Sec. 50-135. - Minimum right-of-way widths. Minimum right-of-way widths for acceptance of city streets are as follows:
In addition, street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible, and no intersection shall be at an angle less than 75 degrees. (Ord. of 1996, § VI) Sec. 50-136. - Basic construction standards. (a) Grading. All streets, roads and alleys shall be graded by the subdivider to provide the necessary paving, roadway, drainage, and safety requirements. (b) Storm drainage. An adequate drainage system including necessary curbs, pipes, culverts, headwalls and ditches as appropriate shall be provided for the property drainage of all surface water. Pipe size will be determined by the use of rational method or the peak discharge method. (c) Slopes and shoulder improvements. The minimum ratio for all fill or cut slopes (including drainage ditches) shall be two to one and the minimum width for all shoulders from back edge of the curb, if installed, shall be eight feet. All shoulders shall slope one-half inch to the foot. When all construction is completed, all slopes and shoulders shall be cleared of all rubbish and shall have a stand of grass to prevent undue erosion, either by sprigging or seeding. (Ord. of 1996, § VII) Sec. 50-137. - Roadway surfacing and paving. The minimum requirements to be adhered to for the surfacing and paving of streets proposed to be conveyed to the city shall adhere to the minimum requirements established by the city and on file in the office of the city clerk or the minimum standards established by the state department of transportation for use in the state highway system. (Ord. of 1996, § VIII) Sec. 50-138. - Minimum pavement width. All residential streets paved after the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall have a minimum pavement width of 27 feet from back of curb to back of curb, or 24 feet from edge of pavement to edge of pavement if no curb or gutters are installed. The outside pavement for a cul-de-sac turnaround shall be a minimum diameter of 80 feet. (Ord. of 1996, § IX) Sec. 50-139. - When roadways accepted by the city. Streets and roadways when accepted by the city shall be on appropriate right-of-way deeds which convey fee simple title to such rights-of-ways together with appropriate easements for ditches, slopes and drainage easements prepared by, or at the expense of the developer or subdivider and approved by the city and without restriction or reservation. (Ord. of 1996, § XI)

div.head: Chapter 52 - SUBDIVISIONS
div.p: (RESERVED)

div.head: Chapter 54 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Revenue and taxation generally, O.C.G.A. § 48-1-1 et seq.; ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.; county tax officials and administration, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-100 et seq.; county taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-220 et seq.; municipal taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.; miscellaneous local administration provisions, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-380; sales and use taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-8-1 et seq.; taxes on tobacco products, O.C.G.A. § 48-11-1 et seq.; levy of occupation taxes by counties and municipalities on certain businesses, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq.; imposition of regulatory fees by local governments on certain businesses, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-8 et seq.; authority of counties and municipalities to impose excise tax on lodging and accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 54-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases shall, for the purpose of this article and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, be defined as follows: Due date means the 20th day after the end of the monthly period for which tax is to be computed. Guestroom means a room occupied, or intended, arranged, or designed for occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. Monthly period means a calendar month.
