Motel means any structure or any portion of a structure, including any motel, lodginghouse, roominghouse, dormitory, Turkish bath, bachelor hotel, hotel, motor hotel, auto court, inn, bed and breakfast inn, public club, or private club, containing guestrooms and which is occupied, or is intended or designed for occupancy by guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor, or otherwise. Such term does not include any jail, hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, prison, detention center, or other buildings in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession of any room or apartment in a motel, or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room. Occupant or guest means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any room in a motel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement, or otherwise. Operator means any person operating a motel in the city including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, the lessee, sublessee, lender in possession, licensee, or any other person otherwise operating such motel. Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. Return means any return filed or required to be filed as herein provided. Tax means taxes imposed by this chapter or any other chapter of this Code. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-1, 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-2. - Police chief authorized to conduct sales. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-359, the city police chief or his designee is authorized to conduct sales of real and personal property on behalf of the city including, but not limited to, sales of real and personal properly taken for taxes due the city. (Ord. of 1-13-2004, § 2) Secs. 54-3—54-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - HOTEL AND MOTEL EXCISE TAX DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 54-56. - Imposition and rate of tax. (a) The city has levied and imposed a tax in the percentage of the rent set by state law for every occupancy of a guestroom in a motel in the city, provided that levy shall be given to the chamber of commerce to subsidize the salaries of the chamber of commerce employees whose responsibility it is to promote tourism as pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(3). (b) The tax levied herein shall be paid upon any occupancy occurring on or after October, 1, 1996, although such occupancy is had pursuant to a contract, lease, or other arrangement made prior to such date. Where rent is paid, or charged or billed, or falls due on either a weekly, monthly or other term basis, the rent so paid, charged, billed or falling due shall be subject to the tax herein imposed to the extent that it covers any portion of the month of October 1996, and any portion of any monthly period thereafter. (c) No tax shall be levied as provided in this section upon the fees or charges for any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations furnished for a period of more than ten consecutive days or for use as meeting rooms. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-2, 10-1-1996) State Law reference— Authority of counties and municipalities to impose excise tax on lodging and accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51. Sec. 54-57. - Collection of tax by operator. It shall be the duty of every operator of a motel located within the city to collect from the occupants the tax levied and imposed upon the occupancy of guestrooms by the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-3, 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-58. - Exemptions. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, no tax shall be levied as provided in this article upon the fees or charges for any rooms, lodgings or accommodations furnished for use by state or local government officials or employees when traveling on official business. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-4, 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-59. - Registration of operator; separate registration required for each location. Every person engaging or about to engage in business as an operator of a motel in this city shall immediately register with the city clerk on a form provided by the clerk. The registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his places of business and such other information as the city clerk may require. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; by a member or partner in case of ownership by an association or partnership; and by an executive officer in the case of ownership by a corporation. A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-5, 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-60. - Certificate of taxing authority. Upon the registration of an operator, the city clerk shall issue to such operator without charge a certificate of authority to collect the tax from the occupants, stating the name and location of the business to which it is applicable. Such certificates shall be nonassignable and nontransferable, and shall be returned immediately to the city clerk upon the cessation of business by the registered operator at the location named, or upon sale or transfer of such business at said location. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-6, 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-61. - Due date. All taxes levied and imposed by this article shall be due and payable to the city monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective monthly period in which such taxes are collected. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-7, 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-62. - Returns and time of filing; remittance of tax. On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the clerk, in such form as the city clerk may prescribe, by every operator liable for the payment of tax hereunder. All returns shall show the gross rent, exempt rent, taxable rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the monthly period for which filed, and such other information as may be required by the city clerk, and shall be accompanied when filed by remittance of the net amount of tax due. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-8, 10-1-1996) State Law reference— Filing of returns and payment of taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-53.2. Sec. 54-63. - Collection fee allowed operators. Operators collecting the tax levied hereunder shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting, and payment of the amount due, if said amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from state sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-50. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-9, 10-1-1996) State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-52. Secs. 54-64—54-84. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - DEFICIENCY DETERMINATIONS
Sec. 54-85. - Clerk's authority; recomputation of tax; interest; offset by overpayment. (a) Recomputation of tax; authority to make; basis of recomputation. If the city clerk is not satisfied with the return of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any person, he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information in his possession or which may come into his possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. (b) Interest on deficiency. The amount of the unpaid tax found to be due shall bear interest at the rate of three-fourths of one percent per month from and after the 20th day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount should have been returned until the date of payment of such tax and interest. (c) Offsetting of overpayment. In making a determination, the clerk may offset overpayment for a period, or periods, against unpaid tax found to be due for another period, against penalties, and against the interest on such unpaid tax. (d) Service of notice. The city clerk or his designated representative shall give to the operator written notice of his determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail. If by mail, such service shall be addressed to the operator at his address as it appears in the records of the city clerk. (e) Time within which notice may be given. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period shall last expire. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-10, 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-86. - Determination if no return made. (a) Estimate of gross receipts. If any operator fails to make a return, the city clerk shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the operator or, as the case may be, of the amount of the total rentals in this city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period in respect to which the person failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the city clerk. Upon the basis of this estimate the city clerk shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid the city, adding to the sum thus determined a penalty equal to 15 percent thereof. One or more determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. (b) Offsetting of overpayment. In making a determination, the city clerk may offset overpayment for a period, or periods, against unpaid tax found to be due for another period, against penalties, and against interest on unpaid tax found to be due. The interest on such unpaid tax shall be computed in the manner set forth in this division. (c) Interest on amount found due. The amount of the unpaid tax found to be due shall bear interest at the rate of three-fourths of one percent per month from and after the 20th day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount should have been returned until the date of payment of such tax, penalties, and interest. (d) Method of giving written notice. Promptly after making his determination, the city clerk shall give to the operator written notice of his determination, which notice may be served personally or by mail in the manner prescribed for service of notice of a deficiency determination. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-11, 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-87. - Collection of tax. (a) Time within which action must be taken. When it is determined by a return filed, or by the city clerk having made a determination that tax is due and payable to the city under the provisions of this article, the city clerk may at any time within three years after determination that such tax is due and payable bring an action in the appropriate court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the city to collect the amount of tax payable to the city together with interest thereon and penalties, court costs, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. The bringing of such an action shall not be a prerequisite for the issuance of a fi.fa. under the provisions of this section. (b) Duty of successors or assignees of operator to withhold tax from purchase money. If any operator liable for any amount of tax under this article sells or transfers his business, his successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient amount of the purchase price of the business to cover such amount of tax, interest thereon, and penalties, and pay such sum over to the city, unless the operator liable for such tax delivers to such purchaser or transferee, as the case may be, at the time of such sale or transfer, a certificate from the city clerk showing that all tax returns required of such operator have been filed and all taxes shown as being payable on said returns have been paid in full. (c) Liability for failure to withhold; time to enforce successor's liability. If the purchaser or transferee of a business fails to withhold the required amount of the purchase price, he shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price, valued in money. The time within which the obligation of a successor may be enforced shall start to run at the time the operator sells or transfers his business, or at the time that the determination against the operator becomes final, whichever event occurs the later. (d) Issuance of fi.fa. The city clerk is hereby authorized to issue a fi.fa. for execution and levy to satisfy the amount of any tax, penalty, or interest due but not paid under the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-12, 10-1-1996) Secs. 54-88—54-117. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 54-118. - Authority of clerk. The city clerk shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the levy and collection of the tax imposed by this article. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-13(a), 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-119. - Additional rules and regulations. The city clerk shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this article or with federal and state law for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and the collection of the taxes hereunder. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-13(b), 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-120. - Records required; audit. Every operator shall keep such records, receipts, invoices, and other pertinent papers in such form as the city clerk may require. The city clerk or any person authorized in writing by him, may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment, and other facilities of any operator in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount of tax required to be paid. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-13(c)—(d), 10-1-1996) State Law reference— Preservation of books and records and examination by governing authority, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-53.4. Sec. 54-121. - Reports required; contents. In administration of the provisions of this article, the city clerk may require the filing of reports by any person or class of persons having in such person's possession or custody information relating to rentals of guestrooms which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the city clerk when required by the city clerk and shall set forth the rental charged for each occupancy, the dates of occupancy, and such other information as the city clerk may require. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-13(e), 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-122. - Confidentiality; limitations on disclosure. The city clerk or any person having an administrative duty under this article shall not make known in any manner: (1) The business affairs, operations, or information obtained by an audit of books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator or any other person visited or examined in the discharge of official duty; (2) The amount or source of income, profits, losses, expenditures, or any particular thereof, set forth or disclosed in any return; or (3) Permit any return or copy thereof or any book containing any abstract or particulars thereof to be seen or examined by any person not having such administrative duty under this article; except in the case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the tax hereby levied and assessed. Successors, receivers, trustees, executors, administrators, assignees and guarantors, if directly interested, may be given information as to the items included in the measure and amount of unpaid tax or amounts of tax, interest and penalties required to be collected. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-13(f), 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-123. - Designated agent required. (a) When registering as required in this article, each operator shall appoint, in writing, an agent to receive for the operator any notice required to be given to the operator under the provisions of this article, stating the full name, street address, mailing address and telephone number of such agent. (b) The agent shall be either an individual resident of the city or an employee of the operator who regularly works at the operator's place of business on a daily basis, and the appointment of the agent must be accompanied by the written consent of such agent to serve as agent for the operator. The agent may be changed from time to time by written appointment of, and consent of, a successor agent. (c) The operator is required to have an agent at all times and should an agent cease to be a resident of the city or an employee regularly working at the operator's place of business in the city, as the case may be, the operator shall immediately file a written appointment of a new agent and such agent's consent to serve as such with the city clerk. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-14, 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-124. - Duties of agent regarding service and notice. Any agent appointed by an operator shall be authorized to receive for and on behalf of the operator any notice required to be given to the operator by the provisions of this article. Delivery of any such notice to such agent, in person or by mail, shall be sufficient to meet the requirements of this article and such notice shall be binding on the operator. This method of giving notice to operators is supplementary and cumulative of the other methods of giving notice set forth in this article. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-14, 10-1-1996) Sec. 54-125. - Violations and penalties. Any operator or other person who fails to register as required herein, or to furnish any return required to be made, or who fails or refuses to furnish a supplemental return or other data required by the city clerk, or who renders a false or fraudulent return, and any person required to make, render, sign, or verify any report who makes any false or fraudulent report, with intent to defeat or evade the determination of an amount due, shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-15. (Ord. No. 96-11, § 32-15, 10-1-1996) State Law reference— Failure, neglect or refusal to collect tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-59; making false or fraudulent return, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-60; failure or refusal to furnish return or supplemental return, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-61; failure to keep records or open records to inspection, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-62.

div.head: Chapter 56 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS[1]
Chapter 58 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq.; uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; off-road vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-7-1 et seq.; equipment and inspection of motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-1 et seq.; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq.; use of speed detection devices, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2 et seq.; cities and counties authorized to enact ordinances for removal of vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 58-1. - Penalty. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished in accordance with section 1-15. Secs. 58-2—58-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 58-21. - Traffic control devices. (a) The street department shall place and maintain traffic control signs, signals, and devices when and as required under the traffic ordinances of this city to make effective the provisions of such ordinances, and may place and maintain such additional traffic control devices as may be deemed necessary to regulate traffic under the traffic ordinances of this city or under state law. (b) The street department is authorized to place markers, buttons, turtles, lines, or signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning at such intersections. (c) The street department is hereby authorized to determine those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall not make a right or left turn and shall place proper signs at such intersections. (d) The street department is hereby authorized to take the following action: (1) Designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks, or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in its opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as may be deemed necessary; (2) Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as may be deemed necessary for the protection of pedestrians; (3) Mark lanes for traffic and spaces for parking and loading on street pavements at such places as may be deemed advisable, consistent with the traffic ordinances of this city. (e) The street department shall determine upon what streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such street accordingly. State Law reference— Authority to regulate traffic by means of official traffic control devices preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(2); traffic signs, signals, etc., O.C.G.A. § 40-6-20 et seq. Sec. 58-22. - Authority of police and fire department officials to enforce chapter. It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department and such officers as are assigned by the chief of police to such duty to enforce all traffic laws of this city. In addition, officers of the fire department when at the scene of a fire may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity. State Law reference— Authority to regulate traffic by means of police officers preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1); obedience to persons directing traffic required, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-2. Sec. 58-23. - Records of traffic violations. The police department shall keep a record of all violations of the traffic ordinances of this city with which any person has been charged, together with a record of the final disposition of all such alleged offenses. All such records and reports shall be public records. Sec. 58-24. - Traffic accidents. It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department to investigate traffic accidents, to arrest and to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with violations of law causing or contributing to such accidents, and to file and maintain records containing such accident reports. State Law reference— Accidents and accident reports, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-270 et seq. Sec. 58-25. - Issuance of summons. (a) Any police officer upon making an arrest for violation of this chapter shall issue a summons to the alleged offender, directing him to appear at the next session of the municipal court, as the case may be, to answer the charges against him, requiring such bond as the police department may from time to time specify, but sufficient to ensure the appearance in court of alleged offender. (b) Service of a summons upon an alleged parking offender by affixing same to the illegally parked vehicle shall be legal and sufficient service upon the alleged offender requiring him to appear in court as directed. Sec. 58-26. - Impoundment and disposition of motor vehicles. (a) Any person, at the direction of the chief of police or a duly certified police officer, is hereby authorized to remove, or have removed at his direction, a vehicle, from any public or private way or place, under any of the circumstances hereinafter enumerated, the council hereby finding and determining such vehicles under such circumstances to be obstructions to traffic or public nuisances. Such vehicle is authorized to be removed under any of the following circumstances: (1) When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct, subway or tunnel, or where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic; (2) When a vehicle upon a public way is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the person in charge of the vehicle is by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal; (3) When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street or parked illegally so as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic, or left unattended on any public street with engine running or with keys in the ignition switch or locked; (4) When any vehicle is parked or left standing upon any area or portion of a public street in violation of or contrary to a parking limitation or prohibition established by the chief of police; provided, such area or portion of such public street has been posted with an official sign giving notice both of such limitation or prohibition and of the fact that such area or portion of such street is a tow-away area; (5) When a vehicle is parked in violation of any traffic ordinance and is an obstruction or hazard or potential obstruction or hazard to any lawful function or limits the normal access to a use of any public or private property; (6) When the driver of such vehicle is taken into custody by the police department and the vehicle would thereby be left unattended upon a street, highway or restricted parking area, or other public way; (7) When the driver of a vehicle is reasonably suspected of using license plates or license permits unlawfully, misusing a license plate or license permit issued to the driver, or a vehicle is parked without proper license plates or license permits, or with no license plates or license permits or driven or parked with an invalid or expired license permit; (8) When the driver of a vehicle is driving without an operator's license or chauffeur's license which is current and valid, or who does not have such license in his immediate possession, or who drives a vehicle contrary to restrictions imposed upon the license, or who drives a vehicle while their operator's or chauffeur's license has been denied, suspended, cancelled, or revoked by the state; (9) When a vehicle is found parked on or so near to any railroad track as to block the same in any manner; (10) When any truck-tractor is found to be parked in any metered parking space; (11) When any semitrailer is found to be parked in any metered parking space; (12) When the driver of any vehicle, or the vehicle which the driver is driving, is reasonably suspected of having been involved in any hit and run accident; (13) When any vehicle is reasonably suspected of being a stolen vehicle, or parts thereof to be stolen parts; (14) When the driver of any vehicle is taken into custody for suspected felony or misdemeanor, or when the vehicle is suspected of containing stolen goods, or other contraband; (15) When any vehicle is parked or stopped in an emergency access lane in violation of or contrary to a parking limitation or prohibition established by city ordinance; provided that such emergency access lane has been posted with an authorized sign giving notice both of such limitation or prohibition and of the fact that such area or portion of such public roadway or private property is a tow-away area. (b) The owner of any vehicle so removed and impounded shall be required to pay storage and other costs incurred by virtue of such removal and impounding, regardless of the cause of the conduct necessitating such action by the police department. State Law reference— Disposition of personal property in the custody of law enforcement agencies, O.C.G.A. § 17-5-4 ; authority to remove vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-3. Secs. 58-27—58-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC REGULATIONS
Sec. 58-56. - Adoption of uniform rules of the road. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370, the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq., known as the uniform rules of the road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect, as if recited in this chapter. Sec. 58-57. - Parental responsibility. It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian, or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor under the age of 16 years to permit, whether knowingly or through ineffective control or supervision, such minor to violate any provision of this Code or state law regarding the operation of vehicles. Sec. 58-58. - Temporary regulations. In cases where traffic upon the roads of the city may become congested upon occasions of parades, at theaters, and other public assemblages where large numbers of vehicles are assembled, the chief of police may make temporary rules directing and regulating the traffic in these congested districts, and any person who, after being warned of the temporary traffic regulations, shall violate them, shall be liable therefore as for other violations of this Code. Sec. 58-59. - Authorized emergency vehicles. (a) The driver of any authorized emergency vehicle when responding to an emergency call or when in the pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law or when responding to, but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may exercise the privileges set forth in this section but subject to the conditions herein stated. (b) The exemptions herein granted to an authorized emergency vehicle shall apply only when the driver of and said vehicle while in motion sounds audible signal by bell, siren or exhaust whistle as may be reasonably necessary and when the vehicle is equipped with at least one lighted lamp displaying a red light visible under normal atmospheric conditions from a distance of 500 feet to the front of such vehicle, except that an authorized emergency vehicle operated as a police vehicle need not be equipped with or display a red light visible from in front of the vehicle. (c) This section shall not be construed to relieve the driver of any authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. (d) Subject to the foregoing limitations, the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may: (1) Park or stand irrespective of the provisions of this chapter. (2) Proceed past a traffic light or stop sign, but only slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation. (3) Exceed the speed limits specified so long as he does not endanger life or property. (4) Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions so long as he does not endanger life or property. Sec. 58-60. - Improper operation of off-road vehicles. (a) This section shall be considered as cumulative to any and all other laws, rules and regulations regarding the subject matter; however, if this section is in conflict with existing rules, regulations and resolutions, then where it is in conflict this section shall prevail and be considered governing. (b) Unless the context otherwise requires, the term "off-road vehicle," as used in this section, shall mean: (1) Any motorized vehicle designed for or capable of cross-country travel on or immediately over land, water, snow, ice, marsh, swampland, or other natural terrain and not intended for use predominantly on public roads. (2) The term includes, but is not limited to, four-wheel-drive or low-pressure-tire vehicles, two-wheel vehicles (including trail bikes and minibikes), amphibious machines, ground-effect or air-cushion vehicles, and any other means of transportation deriving power from any source other than muscle or wind. The term "off-road vehicle" does not include any motorboats; any military, fire or law enforcement vehicles; any vehicles used exclusively on airports; all farm machinery, farm tractors, and other self-propelled equipment for harvesting and transportation of forest products, for clearing land, for planting, for utility service and maintenance, for earth moving, or for construction or mining; and self-propelled lawnmowers, snow blowers, garden or lawn tractors, or golf carts while such vehicles are being used exclusively for its designed purposes. (c) As authorized by O.C.G.A. § 40-7-5, any person operating an off-road vehicle in the city under any of the following conditions shall be deemed to be in violation of this section: (1) Without operative brakes, or without mufflers or other silencing equipment. (2) In such a manner as to make, continue to make, or cause to be made any loud, unnecessary or unusual sound or noise which either endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others in the city, and which is audible to a person of normal hearing ability more than 50 feet from the point of origin of such sound or noise. (3) On any private property without the property owner or his agent being present or without being in possession of the expressed written permission of the property owner or his agent. (4) On the right-of-way of any street, highway, avenue, lane, public throughway, etc., of the city. (5) On the roadway of any street or highway of the city without complying with all appropriate state laws and city ordinances. Sec. 58-61. - Sale of vehicles on rights-of-way prohibited. (a) It shall be unlawful to park or leave unattended on or within the right-of-way of any public road in the incorporated areas of the city any used motor vehicle that is marked for sale or otherwise displayed for sale. A vehicle shall be considered to be displayed for sale when a reasonable person would perceive that the vehicle is for sale without having to inquire whether the vehicle is for sale. (b) The law enforcement officials of the city are authorized and empowered to impound any vehicle found to be in violation of this section. The owner of such vehicle shall be responsible for all expenses and charges incurred in the towing and storage of the vehicle. Sec. 58-62. - Use of bicycles restricted in business district. No person shall operate a bicycle upon any sidewalk in the business district of this city. This section shall not prohibit children from moving bicycles on sidewalks in such area while dismounted. State Law reference— Authority to regulate persons on toy vehicles preserved, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(18); bicycles and play vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-290 et seq. Sec. 58-63. - Excessive vehicle noise. No person shall cause or permit the vehicle he is driving to emit music that can be heard 100 feet or more from his or vehicle, whether the windows in the vehicle are up or down. Any person violating this section shall be subject to the penalty as provided in section 1-15. (Ord. of 10-4-1994) Secs. 58-64—58-115. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SPEED REGULATION[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Maximum speed limits, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-181; power of local authorities to alter speed limits, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183.
Sec. 58-116. - Speed detection device authorized. The law enforcement officers of the city are authorized to use speed detection devices as permitted by O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2. (Res. of 5-11-1992) State Law reference— Georgia Peace Officer Training Act, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq.; authority for use or speed detection devices by local law enforcement officers, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2; requirements that local government obtain state permit, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2. Sec. 58-117. - Local speed regulations for on-system and off-system arterial streets and roads. In addition to and alteration of the state speed limits as provided by statute, and pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183, the following on-system and off-system speed restrictions for arterial streets and roads are applicable within the geographical limits of the city: (1) On-system. a. State Route 26 from the city limit (M.L. 4.19) to City Street #556-Jessup Street (M.L. 4.65), a distance of 0.46 mile to be zoned 45 mph. b. State Route 26 from City Street #556-Jessup Street (M.L. 4.65) to County Road #14-Thompson Road (M.L. 5.22), a distance of 0.57 mile to be zoned 35 mph. c. State Route 26 from County Road #14-Thompson Road (M.L. 5.22) to City Street #595-Third Street (M.L. 5.49), a distance of 0.27 mile to be zoned 25 mph. d. State Route 26 from City Street #595-Third Street (M.L. 5.49) to the city limit (M.L. 6.39), a distance of 0.90 mile to be zoned 35 mph. e. State Route 26, school zone from a point 0.10 mile east of City Street #516-Eighth Street (M.L. 6.06) to City Street #596-Peter Street NE (M.L. 6.30), a distance of 0.24 mile to be zoned 30 mph from 7:45 a.m. to 8:45 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 3:45 p.m. on school days only. f. State Route 87 Business from the Cochran city limit (M.L. 0.30) to a point 0.10 mile south of County Road #221-Thompson Road (M.L. 0.57), a distance of 0.27 mile to be zoned 45 mph. g. State Route 87 Business from a point 0.10 mile south of County Road #221-Thompson Road (M.L. 0.57) to State Route 26 (M.L. 1.68), a distance of 1.11 mile to be zoned 35 mph. h. State Route 87 Business from State Route 26 (M.L. 1.68) to City Street #519-Ash Street (M.L. 1.98), a distance of 0.30 mile to be zoned 25 mph. i. State Route 87 Business from City Street #519-Ash Street (M.L. 1.98) to City Street #505-Phillips Street (M.L. 2.38), a distance of 0.40 mile to be zoned 35 mph. j. State Route 87 Business from City Street #505-Phillips Street (M.L. 2.38) to the city limit (M.L. 3.00), a distance of 0.62 mile to be zoned 45 mph. (2) Off-system. a. County Road #217-Limestone Road from the Cochran city limit to City Street #541, a distance of 0.27 mile to be zoned 35 mph. b. County Road #246-Porter Road from the city limit to County Road #27, a distance of 0.32 mile to be zoned 45 mph. c. County Road #246-Porter Road from County Road #27 to State Route 87 Business, a distance of 0.46 mile to be zoned 35 mph. d. County Road #519-Ash Street from State Route 87 Business to County Road #55, a distance of 0.86 mile to be zoned 35 mph. Sec. 58-118. - Local speed regulations for nonarterial streets. In addition to and alteration of the state speed limits as provided by statute, the following speed restrictions for nonarterial streets and roads are applicable within the geographical limits of the city:
(Ord. No. 79-8, 8-21-1979) Sec. 58-119. - Reduction of speed when speed hazards exist. (a) No person shall drive a vehicle on a street or highway at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the existing conditions and with due regard for the actual and potential hazards that exist. In every event speed shall be so controlled as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle or other conveyance on or entering the street, road, highway or other avenues of travel, in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care and caution. (b) Where no speed hazards exist that require lower speed for compliance with subsection (a) of this section, the speed of any vehicle not less than the minimum limits or not in excess of the maximum limits or established as authorized herein, shall be lawful, but no speed in excess of the maximum limits specified in this section, or established as authorized by this section, shall be unlawful unless special hazards exist that might require lower speed for compliance with subsection (a) of this section. State Law reference— Alteration of speed limits by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183. Secs. 58-120—58-136. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PARKING
Sec. 58-137. - Parking restricted in certain locations. Without limitation, parking shall be restricted in the following locations to the extent indicated: (1) No parking shall be allowed at anytime in a zone beginning at the south city limits of State Route 87 and extending north on said State Route 87 to State Route 87 Spur, Ann Street, the total of two blocks on each side of the street, said street known as Second Street. (2) No parking shall be allowed at any time in a zone beginning 100 feet from the intersection of Third Street and Ann Street extending 100 feet each way on Ann Street and 100 feet each way on Third Street. (3) Parking is prohibited on State Route 26 for a distance of 200 feet on both north and south sides, from Milepost 5.73 to Milepost 5.77. This is 100 feet east and 100 feet west of the intersection of Sixth Street. (4) Parking is prohibited on State Route 26 on both sides of the highway, from the eastern city limits to the western city limits. (Code 1999, § 6-883; Ord. of 12-16-1969; Ord. of 3-24-1970; Ord. No. 76-9, 9-8-1976; Ord. No. 76-10, 9-8-1976; Ord. No. 79-15, 11-15-1979; Ord. of 11-14-1995; Ord. of 4-2-1996) Secs. 58-138—58-157. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - ABANDONED VEHICLES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Junk dealers, 43-22-1 et seq.; removal of junk vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4.
Sec. 58-158. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Old or abandoned automobile (or any other motor vehicle) means: (1) Any automobile or any other motor vehicle that is inoperable due to missing parts, such as an engine or motor, tires or wheels, or any other part necessary to make the automobile or motor vehicle operable; (2) Any automobile or any other motor vehicle which does not have properly displayed a current state or other state required motor vehicle inspection sticker; and (3) Any automobile or any other motor vehicle that does not have properly displayed a current state or other state license tag, including historical tags. (Ord. No. 99-4, § 3, 6-15-1999) Sec. 58-159. - Storage prohibited. It shall be illegal to store old or abandoned automobiles, other motor vehicles, motorcycles or, any other form of mechanized transportation, or its scrap parts, on any residential lot or other location within the city limits. (Ord. No. 99-4, § 1, 6-15-1999) Sec. 58-160. - Notice to owner of violation. The owner of any lot found to be in violation of this article as stated will be given a 20-day notice to remove the offending vehicle prior to a summons being issued. (Ord. No. 99-4, § 2, 6-15-1999) Sec. 58-161. - Impounding vehicles authorized. (a) Whenever a police officer or other officer acting under authority of and as directed by the city shall find any vehicle parked on any street or other place in violation of law or in violation of the ordinances of the city, or abandoned on any street or other public place, and such officer is unable to find the owner, operator, or other person responsible for the same in the immediate vicinity after making a reasonable search and investigation, it shall be his duty to take possession of such vehicle and tow it to a place of storage and keep it in possession of the city until claimed by the person entitled to its possession, if claimed within the time herein fixed; provided, however, that the person claiming the same shall pay all lawful costs as herein fixed. If deemed necessary by such officer, he shall call upon a garageman or other person equipped for towing and storing such vehicles to remove said vehicle and store it. (b) Whenever any officer shall find upon any street or at any other place within the city, any vehicle broken-down, wrecked, disabled, stalled, or in any condition or situation as to render the same likely to immediately endanger life, limb or property, and the owner, operator or person in charge is unable or unwilling to take the proper steps, or unreasonably neglects to take the proper steps to remove the danger or to make the necessary correction with reasonable promptness, said officer shall cause the vehicle to be removed, impounded and kept in the manner specified in subsection (a) of this section, to be released upon compliance with the requirements of this article as to payment of costs and expenses. (c) In all cases where the operator of a vehicle is found, upon the public streets or public places of the city, ill, injured, intoxicated, or for any reason in a condition rendering him unfit to operate the vehicle, said officers may tow away and store such vehicle in the manner above provided, until released by compliance with the requirements of this article. Sec. 58-162. - Redemption of impounded vehicles. The owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle impounded pursuant to this article may redeem said vehicle at any time within 30 days of the date of impoundment by paying the actual costs of impounding, towing and storing said vehicle, plus any penalty that may be assessed for violation of this chapter. Sec. 58-163. - Sale of unredeemed vehicles. In the event the owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle impounded fails to redeem same, as provided in this article, the city may proceed to effectuate its disposition by selling it after advertising said sale in the official city newspaper four times. Said sale shall be by public auction for cash.

div.head: Chapter 60 - UTILITIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Public utilities generally, O.C.G.A. § 46-1-1 et seq.; municipal home rule, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; municipal utilities, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-5; Georgia Water Quality Control Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-20 et seq.; water resources, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-1 et seq.; public water systems, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-170 et seq.; water supply, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-470; sewage and waste disposal, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-29 et seq.; refusal by city or county to supply water because of indebtedness of prior owner, occupant, or lessee prohibited and limited liens for unpaid utility charges, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-17; dumping certain wastes in storm or sanitary sewers prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-2; adoption of ordinances, rules and regulations relating to payment for street improvements and construction of water, gas and sewer connections; payment of costs of connections, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-7; grants of state funds to municipal corporations for public purposes, O.C.G.A. § 36-40-20 et seq.; executions for collection of assessments for laying sewers, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-358.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 60-1. - Unlawful use of services; injury, interference with property of utilities. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to: (1) Intentionally and without authority and permission from the owner thereof injure or destroy any meter, pipe, conduit, wire, pole, lamp, manhole cover, fireplug, or any accessories thereto belonging to the city, the Cochran Water Works or any other public or private utility (hereinafter called the owner) engaged in the manufacture or sale of electricity, gas, water, telephone, television, the furnishing of sanitary sewer service, or other public services without the intent to pay the fair cost of repair or replacement thereof; (2) Intentionally and without authority and permission from the owner utilize any such service or consume any such product with intent to not pay the regular charge therefor to the owner, but with the intent to deprive the owner thereof; (3) Intentionally and without authority prevent a meter from registering the quantity of such service or product supplied with the intent to deprive the owner of its regular charge therefor; (4) In any way interfere with the proper action of any such owner with intent to divert any service or product so as to deprive the owner of the regular charge therefor; or (5) Otherwise intentionally and without authority use or cause to be used, without the consent of such owner, any product or service furnished, manufactured, sold or distributed by such owner with intent to deprive the owner of its regular charge therefor. (b) Proof that a person performed any of the acts set forth in this section or proof that a person knowingly received the benefits of such acts or proof that any of the acts specified in this section were done on the premises in possession of a person with that person's knowledge shall be prima facie evidence that such person is responsible for such prohibited acts. (Ord. No. 96-2, § I, 2-6-1996) State Law reference— Damaging, injuring or interfering with property of public utility companies, municipalities or political subdivision O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. Sec. 60-2. - Rates for city utility and other services. Rates for city water, sewer, gas, and other services, including garbage services, shall be in the amount specified by the city council. A schedule of rates is available in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. No. 09-4, 6-16-2009) Secs. 60-3—60-62. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY WATER USE REGULATIONS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 60-63. - Declaration of policy. (a) It is hereby declared that the general welfare requires that the water resources available to the city be put to the maximum beneficial use to the extent to which they are capable, and that the waste or unreasonable use, or unreasonable method of use of water be prevented, and the conservation of such water is to be extended with a view to the reasonable and beneficial use thereof in the interests of the people of the area served by the city's water resources and for the public welfare. (b) In making decisions under this article concerning the allocation of water between conflicting interests, highest priority will be given to allocation necessary to support human life and health (i.e., the minimum amount of water necessary for drinking, prevention of disease, and the like). Second highest priority will be given to allocations that will result in the least loss of employment to persons whose income is essential to their families. Sec. 60-64. - Authorization. The mayor or his designee, upon the recommendation of the water superintendent, is hereby authorized and directed to implement the applicable provisions of this article upon determination that such implementation is necessary to protect the public welfare and safety. Sec. 60-65. - Compliance required. No person shall knowingly, recklessly, or with criminal negligence make, cause, use, or permit the use of water from the city system for residential, commercial, industrial, agricultural, governmental, or any other purpose in a manner contrary to any provision of this article, or in an amount in excess of that use permitted by the conservation stage in effect pursuant to action taken by the mayor or his designee, in accordance with the provision of this section. The provisions of this article shall apply to all uses of water from the city water supply system wherever situated. Sec. 60-66. - Water use guidelines. The mayor or his designee shall promulgate guidelines that shall set forth the criteria for determining when a particular conservation state is to be implemented and terminated and the use restrictions applicable during each stage established. Such guidelines shall be updated when, in the opinion of the city, the conditions of the water system have changed so as to necessitate such an update and said guidelines are to be published and filed in the office of the water superintendent. Sec. 60-67. - Prohibited and restricted uses. The use of withdrawal of water from the water supply system of the city for the following purposes or uses is hereby regulated during any period of water shortage commencing with the promulgation and implementation of water conservation guidelines by the city and continuing until such water conservation measures are no longer deemed necessary by the city in accordance with such guidelines: (1) Condition I; water shortage possibility. a. Upon implementation by the city, customers of the water system of the city are requested to voluntarily conserve and limit their use and all municipal operations are placed on mandatory conservation. b. Water used for outdoor watering including, but not limited to, watering lawns, gardens, and landscaping; washing automobiles at residential sites; hosing sidewalks, buildings, and driveways; and similar nonessential watering, may be used only between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. and only on even-numbered calendar days for premises with an even street number address and only on odd-numbered calendar days for premises with an odd street number address. No person or customer shall cause or permit water to run or waste in any gutter or otherwise. (2) Condition II; water shortage watch. a. The sprinkling or watering of lawns is permitted on the same schedule as for condition I. b. Additionally, the city may authorize the watering of trees, shrubbery, annual, biennial or perennial plants, vines, gardens, vegetable and flowers through the means of a handheld hose equipped with a positive shutoff nozzle, drip irrigation or a handheld bucket or watering can. When authorized, such watering shall be done only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. on the odd/even day restriction specified above. c. Commercial nurseries shall be excepted from the prohibition of this subsection and shall be permitted to water nursery stock by means of a handheld hose equipped with a positive shutoff nozzle, drip irrigation or handheld bucket or watering can between the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. Commercial nurseries shall be permitted to use sprinkler irrigation systems to maintain nursery stock provided irrigation water is recaptured and recirculated. d. Residential homeowners and occupants may install and water on day of purchase landscape plantings, excluding lawns. e. The washing of automobiles, trucks, trailers, boats, airplanes, and any other type of mobile equipment is prohibited unless the city governing authority by written notice permits individuals to wash their private cars or boats if they use a bucket, pail, or normal sized receptacles; and further provide that filling stations shall wash their customers' cars with a bucket, pan, pail or other receptacle not larger than that of five gallons capacity; however, an individual or filling station, after such washing, shall be permitted to rinse the car or boat off with a hose, using only a reasonable amount of water in so doing. Commercial or automatic car washing establishments shall use minimum practical water settings. f. The washing of building exteriors and interiors, trailers, trailer houses and railroad cars is prohibited except that in the interest of public health the mayor or his designee may permit limited use of the water as the case may be. g. The permitting or maintaining of defective plumbing in a home, business establishment or any location where water is used on the premises is prohibited. The permitting of the wasting of any water by reason of defective plumbing as herein abovementioned shall include the existence of out-of-repair water closets, underground leaks, defective faucets and taps. The permitting of water to flow constantly through a tap, hydrant, valve or otherwise by any user of water connected to the city system, shall be considered as a wasting of water and prohibited. h. The use of fire hydrants for any purpose other than firefighting is prohibited without permission of the city fire chief. i. The use of water in ornamental foundations or in artificial waterfalls where the water is not reused or recirculated in any manner is prohibited. j. The use of water to wash down any sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts or other hard surfaced area, or building or structure is prohibited. k. The use of water for dust control is prohibited except on the odd/even day schedule. l. The use of potable water by a golf course to irrigate any portion of its ground, except those areas designated as tee sand greens and only between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. on the designated watering days, is prohibited. m. Concurrently with the implementation of condition II, the city council may, in its discretion, appoint an allocation and review committee, as herein provided, for the purpose of reviewing water conservation policies and establishing exemptions. (3) Condition III; water shortage warning. a. New service connections to the city's water system are prohibited where some other source independent of the city's water system is existing and in use at the time of passage of this article. b. A mandatory limit of normal water use by customers without use penalty, may be established in amounts as determined by the city. In addition, the city may establish a maximum limit beyond which water service will be terminated. c. The use of water to serve a customer in a restaurant unless requested by the customer is prohibited. d. The use of water for the expansion of commercial nursery facilities is prohibited. e. The use of water for scenic recreational ponds and lakes is prohibited. f. The use of water for private, single-family residential swimming pools, wading pools, Jacuzzi pools, hot tubs, and like or similar uses is prohibited. g. The use of water for municipally owned swimming pools in prohibited. h. The use of water for privately owned neighborhood and subdivision swimming pools accessible to the public and swimming pools owned by country clubs, athletic clubs, health clubs, fraternal organization, and other like or similar pools is prohibited. i. The use of water for hotel, motel, condominium, apartment and other multifamily, residential user swimming pools, including commercial and business swimming pools is prohibited. j. The use of water to put new agricultural land into production is prohibited. k. The use of water for new planting or landscaping is prohibited. l. When watering of plants is authorized by the city, such watering shall be permitted only between the hours of 6:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. on the odd day/even day address limitation of use of water or such other time designated in writing by the city. (4) Condition IV; water shortage emergency. a. No application for new, additional, further expended, or increased-in-size water service connections, meters, service lines, pipeline extensions, mains, or other water service facilities of any kind shall be allowed, approved, or installed, except as approved by the allocation and review committee. b. All allocation of water use to industrial and commercial customers in amounts as established after consultation with the allocation and review committee, if established. c. The maximum monthly use for a residential customer shall be established with revised rate schedules and penalties by the city in recommendation by the allocation and review committee, if established. d. The city shall take those actions deemed necessary to meet the conditions resulting from the emergency. Secs. 60-68—60-92. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ALLOCATION AND REVIEW COMMITTEE
Sec. 60-93. - Composition. The allocation and review committee shall be composed of five members including the mayor, one member of council, the utilities superintendent, a representative of business/commerce and a citizen of the city. The business/commerce and citizen members shall be recommended by the mayor and appointed by the city council and shall serve at the pleasure of the governing authority. Sec. 60-94. - Duties. The committee shall consider requests of water users for special consideration to be given as to their respective particular circumstances and the committee shall hear and decide such requests and is hereby authorized to, in special cases, grant such variance from the terms of this article as will not be contrary to the public interest, where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of this article will result in unnecessary hardship, and so that the spirit of this article shall be observed and substantial justice done. Sec. 60-95. - Special exception permits. Should a permit for special exception be granted by the committee, it shall be in effect from the time of granting; provided that the permit is permanently posted on the premises within two feet of the street number located on the premises. Should protest be received after the granting of any a special permit, the committee shall consider the revocation of such permit and shall reconsider the granting of such permit at a public hearing, notice of which shall have been given at least one day prior to the holding of such hearing. After the conclusion of the hearing, the committee shall take such action by way of revocation of such permit, or refusal to revoke the same or modification of such permit as the committee may deem proper under the circumstances. Secs. 60-96—60-118. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 60-119. - Inspection authority. All members of the city police and fire departments, and those employees of the city designated by the police chief shall be and are hereby authorized to enter upon all property or properties located within the city limits for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement and testing in accordance with and to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 7-11-2000) Sec. 60-120. - Presumption of violation. (a) A person in apparent control of the property where the violation occurs or originates shall be presumed to be the violator, and proof of facts showing apparent control by such persons of the premises and proof that the violation occurred on the premises shall constitute prima facie evidence that said person committed the violation, but said person shall have the right to show that he did not commit the violation. (b) Any person whose name is on file with the city as the customer on the water account for the property where the violation occurs or originates shall be presumed to be the violator, and proof that the violation occurred on said premises shall constitute prima facie evidence that the customer committed the violation, but said customer shall have the right to show that he did not commit the violation. (c) Parents shall be presumed to be responsible for violations of their minor children, and proof that a child committed a violation on property with the parent's control shall constitute prima facie evidence that said parent committed the violation, but said parent may be excused if he proves that he had previously directed the child not to use the water as it was used in the violation and that the parent could not have reasonably known of the violation. Sec. 60-121. - Penalties. Any person, firm, institution or other entity found to be in violation of the provisions of this article shall, upon the first conviction thereof, be fined the sum of $100.00. Upon the second conviction of the violation, the offender shall be fined the sum of $250.00, and water and sewage service to the property upon which the violation occurs shall be disconnected and a reconnection fee of $250.00 shall be charged. Upon a third or subsequent violation, the offender shall be fined the sum of $300.00 and water and sewage service to the property upon which the violation occurred shall be discontinued and a reconnection fee of $500.00 shall be charged. (Ord. of 7-11-2000) Secs. 60-122—60-140. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - NATURAL GAS

The following definitions shall apply to the operation of the natural gas system in the city: Appliances means all stoves, heaters, hot water tanks, conversion units and any other devices in which natural gas is used. City means the City of Cochran, acting through its duly elected mayor and council. Customer means any person, firm or corporation receiving gas service from the high-pressure transmission line. Customer's inlet means the location of the pipe at the customer's premises where gas is delivered to the customer. Gas inspector means the duly authorized person hired by the city to inspect house piping and appliance installations. Gas system means the transmission line from the Southern Natural Line or other supply lines to the city border station of each town and the distribution mains in the city, together with all service lines, valves, meters, cocks, regulating equipment, and other appurtenances necessary to distribute gas to the customers. House piping means the piping in or around the house or building of the customer. Licensee means any person, firm or corporation who has been licensed by the city to install house piping and appliances. Main means a line, part of the distribution system, that transports gas. Service line means line from the main to the customer's inlet. Specifications means the standard specifications of Ray R. Littrell and Associates for the construction of natural gas systems shall be complied with unless other procedures, methods, or specifications are specified in this article or any other provision of this Code. (Code 1999, § 6-501; Ord. of 9-15-1953) Sec. 60-142. - Beginning service. (a) Every person that can be served by the city at a profit will be served natural gas under the city's rules, regulations, and tariffs. The size of the service and appurtenances used to serve each customer shall be such that will render efficient service to the customer. (b) Prospective average customers desiring gas service where the city has an existing main will be furnished, free of charge, 100 feet of service line and the necessary fittings, valves, meter, and regulator. In the event the customer's inlet is over 100 feet from the city's main, a charge will be made by the city for that amount of the service line exceeding 100 feet, piping costs and the cost of locating the wire. (c) Any prospective average customer who desires gas service where the city does not have a main available will be furnished 100 feet of two-inch main free of charge. If the additional main necessary to serve such customer is over 100 feet, the city will charge for that part of the main in excess of 100 feet, piping costs and the cost of locating the wire. (d) Subsections (b) and (c) of this section apply to an average customer. Any prospective customer who is over or under the average will be served by the city on a basis consistent with this section. Under subsection (b) or (c) of this section, if the city is to provide service to the customer and has to cut any driveway, walkway, or sidewalk on the customer's property, the customer will be responsible for the expense of repair to the sidewalk, walkway or driveway and the city assumes no cost or responsibility here in the repair of the sidewalk, walkway or driveway. (e) Each prospective customer must sign up with the city for the service the customer desires. Each prospective customer must obtain for the city an easement over the property where the service will be installed, permitting the city to use this property to lay the gas service and permitting the city ingress and egress to the property for purpose necessary for the operation thereof. (f) Each average prospective customer must make a deposit in the amount established by the city council with the city at the time of signing an application for service. (Code 1999, § 6-502; Ord. of 9-15-1953, § 1) Sec. 60-143. - Authority of inspection; installation and examination of piping, fittings, etc. (a) The city shall appoint a building inspector who is authorized, empowered and directed to inspect the installation, construction or reconstruction of all house piping, appliances, fittings or any other appliances that will transport or use natural gas. (b) No pipe or appliance installed to use natural gas from the mains and service of the gas system shall be installed by any person shall be licensed by the city to do such work. Any applicant for a license who is experienced in this type of work, who is familiar with these rules and regulations and who is a reliable and competent workman, shall be examined by the building inspector. If the building inspector is satisfied that this prospective licensee is capable of doing the work in a first class workmanlike manner, a license shall be issued to such person upon payment of an annual fee in the amount established by the city council. This license will be good for a period of one year from the date issued. This license will be revoked immediately if any licensee shall violate any provisions of this article or shall do any work that is not first class. (c) Every licensee shall test every installation with air by mercury gauge in a manner satisfactory to the building inspector. This test includes all house piping and appurtenances up to and including the shutoff cock of the appliance. No appliance shall be installed without the licensee notifying the building inspector. The building inspector shall witness such test and when the test is satisfactory, sign a certificate that such test has been made at a certain time and for a certain person at a certain location and for a certain number of outlets.
